urn:contentItem:5TSG-JHF1-DXH2-61X3-00000-00Migrant Caravan At U.S. Border Is Harboring More Than 500 Criminals, Homeland Security Claims; White House Drops Effort To Suspend Press Pass For CNN's Jim Acosta; Report: President Donald Trump To Submit Written Answers To Bob Mueller Questions By Thanksgiving; Broward County Election Supervisor Brenda Snipes Resigns After Recount; RPT: Pentagon To Begin Troop Drawback From U.S. Southern Border2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisLOU DOBBS TONIGHT7:00 PM ESTGordon Chang, Harmeet Dhillon, Lynnette Hardaway, Rochelle Richardson, Vince CoglianeseNEWSDomestic111901cb.229Migrant Caravan At U.S. Border Is Harboring More Than 500 Criminals, Homeland Security Claims; White House Drops Effort To Suspend Press Pass For CNN's Jim Acosta; Report: President Donald Trump To Submit Written Answers To Bob Mueller Questions By Thanksgiving; Broward County Election Supervisor Brenda Snipes Resigns After Recount; RPT: Pentagon To Begin Troop Drawback From U.S. Southern BorderLou Dobbs, Edward Lawrence, William La Jeunesse, Claudia Cowan, Gregg Jarrett

(CROSSTALK)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thank you for having us in your home. Guys, I love this squad over there. Thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories, tensions between the United States and China escalating as President Trump and his administration insist on America First foreign policy that includes fair trade, balance trade and respect for the U.S. and U.S. property throughout the world. China's president Xi Jinping and Vice President Mike Pence delivered dueling speeches in Asia over the weekend.

Presenting two very different views of global trade and security. We take that up, we discuss the latest in the U.S.-China relationship. China expert Gordon Chang with us. Also tonight, more in rest in Tijuana as Central American migrants are clashing with hundreds of local Mexican residents who don't want them in their city. President Trump remaining steadfast in his commitment to strong borders warning those in the caravan not to try to enter, not to try to enter the United States illegally.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're not letting people in to our country illegally. And we're not doing a release. We'll do a catch but we're not doing releases. So, if they think they're going to be released into our country like in the old days, like for years and years they catch and release, we're not releasing. They don't get released.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We take up the latest in the situation south of our border. Fox Reporter William La Jeunesse, is reporting tonight from Tijuana and The Daily Caller's Vince Coglianese join us. In California, 80 are dead, nearly 1000 people are still missing as the deadliest fire in the state's history continue to burn ahead of an expected rainstorm. We'll have the latest from California, tonight.

Our top story, drop in the shares of Apple. Another big tech fueling a big selloff on Wall Street today. The Dow Jones Industrial is down almost 400 points. The S&P 500 down 46, the NASDAQ lost more than 200 points. And amidst of the market turmoil, the White House continuing to demand fair trade policies from China ahead of an upcoming meeting that will take place between the President and Xi Jinping at the end of this month.

Edward Lawrence in Washington with the story. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINES NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Lou. Trade fair is part of that market drop. The breaking news tonight, the state department spokeswoman reacted to harsh language by the Chinese without mentioning China following the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit. Now, the statement tonight reads, the United States is proud to agree to promote free and fair trade in the region and combat unfair trade practices.

It is unfortunate that not all economies despite their rhetoric could support these positions. And the cooperation summit fail to issue a joint statement for the first time in 29 years. The China blames the U.S. for spoiling the summit. A spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry saying, it seem like the U.S. attended this APEC meeting with great anger. Speeches and remarks at the meeting openly cause controversy, created discourse, spilling the atmosphere -- or spoiling the atmosphere of the meeting and did not contribute to achieving consensus.

Well, the Vice President brief the President today. This summit seem to escalate the trade dispute towards a trade war as China continues with their trading practices. They are not changing. The Chinese delegation led Vice-Premier supposed to meet in Washington this week, they canceled again. These were prep talks related to the G27 Summit bilateral meeting between President Xi Jinping and President Donald Trump.

The Chinese say the meeting will happen after the bilateral on December 1st, assuming it goes well. Now, former FTC Chairman under President Reagan says, China should not underestimate President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DANIEL OLIVER, FORMER FTC CHAIRMAN: Trump is a very good negotiator. He negotiated with the Canadians and I think the Chinese should take a look at how we negotiated with the Canadians and get ready for more.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now the Vice President told the Chinese the U.S. will not change course unless China changes their trading practices. The market reflected that in part with this hardening to -- part of the hardening tone with the selloff. Lou?

DOBBS: Edward, thanks so much. It's hard some days to tell whether it's hardening or whether it's just an awakening on the part of the Chinese to the fact that this president means business.

LAWRENCE: Yes. And resetting those for fair trade deals.

DOBBS: Absolutely. And international economic order in need of rebalancing across the entire breath of those relationships. Edward, thank you very much. Edward Lawrence reporting from Washington. On the U.S. Southern border tonight, Homeland Security officials say the caravan of Central American migrants consisting of nearly all single adult or teen males and that at least 500 criminals have been identified among the ranks.

There are now about 6000 migrants seeking asylum in Tijuana, Mexico. That is from the United States with thousands more expected to arrive behind them over the coming days. But as Correspondent William La Jeunesse now reports. They aren't receiving a warm welcome at all from the locals.

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Well, Lou, as you know, illegal immigration is not new to Mexico. Generations of Central Americans have used this country as a steppingstone to the United States. But this caravan, how they cross the numbers seem to have awakened a silent now vocal minority against them.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JEUNESSE: Tension in Tijuana.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are here because our government has not taken control of these what we call invasions.

JEUNESSE: Shouting, Hondurans go home and viva Mexico. Riot police Sunday stopped hundreds of Mexicans trying to storm the migrant shelter.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You see people within the migrant caravan smoking weed, drinking, throwing rocks at the cops, causing chaos.

JEUNESSE: These Mexicans oppose illegal immigration and blame officials for allowing in thousands without papers. They fear crime, a loss of jobs, depressed wages in a country where 40 percent already live in poverty.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm not in favor of them coming the way they did. You know, to me, if feels like they invaded.

JEUNESSE: Nearby, a counter protest supporters say Mexico should welcome and protect immigrants.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's important that we consider that our Mexican brothers are also in the same situation.

JEUNESSE: The shelter Sunday remained on lockdown until protesters went home.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There here for work, to have a better life and no troubles. Not troublemakers.

JEUNESSE: More than 6000 caravan migrants arrived in Tijuana. Their shelter looking now like a refugee camp as many realize they cannot easily cross the border and any asylum interviews is at least five weeks away.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I tell them it's better for you to get a job and it's not working right. And then (INAUDIBLE) trying to cross the border.

JEUNESSE: This morning for the first time, the U.S. shut down the San Ysidro Port of Entry. Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen saying in a tweet, CPB believe a "large number of caravan migrants plants to rush the border to gain illegal access to the U.S".

(END VIDEOTAPE)

JEUNESSE: So by shutting down lanes and slowing traffic and increasing wait times, President Trump is sending a message to Mexico City that if you fail to stop these on your southern border you face consequences on the northern one. And Lou, he's doing it in a language that everyone understands, time is money. Lou?

DOBBS: William, thank you very much. William La Jeunesse reporting from the San Ysidro Port of Entry. Rain headed for Northern California this week. Welcome rain bringing conditions that could both help and hinder efforts to put up the deadly campfire which has left at least 77 people dead. Correspondent Claudia Cowan has the latest tonight from Chico, California.

HAROLD SCHAPELHOUMAN, FIRE CHIEF, MENLO PARK, CALIFORNIA: It's a grim task but it's necessary. It really does, you know, help families out because it allows them know what happened, as difficult as it is.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CLAUDIA COWAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The flames may have slowed but the recovery from the devastating California wildfires still in its early stages with the death toll growing each day and the number of people unaccounted for constantly fluctuating.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Let's do this.

COWAN: Now, search crews are in a race against mother nature with rain in the forecast. While it will help put out the fire and improve air quality, rain could trigger mud slides and wash away the remains of those who died in the fire.

MIKE MOHLER, DEPUTY DIRECTOR, CALIFORNIA FORESTRY AND FIRE PREVENTION: The weather that's expected is definitely going to impact operations. It's a - - especially during the recovery. I'm working with the Sheriff's Department and first responders. Again, we have additional resources out there really trying to work ahead of these storms.

COWAN: With more than 50000 left homeless by the campfire, thousands are streaming through a disaster relief center trying to get their lives back together.

KEVIN HANNES, FEDERAL COOPERATING OFFICER, FEMA: They can get initial financial support from FEMA if they qualified for Federal assistance. They can get information, they can get their drivers license renewed, they can update their mailing address with the postal service. Social Security cards can be issued here.

COWAN: An emotional vigil on Sunday night in Chico, California where the community came together to heal and share stories of their escape.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We were basically a moving bomb because we had a bunch of propane tanks.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: There was leaves falling down on fire on top of us. Propane tanks blowing it up. It was -- it was like a war zone.

COWAN: Joe Florence (ph) and his family are thankful they made it out in time. And also for President Trump's visit here on Saturday.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm grateful for all the support that he's given us. He didn't have to come here the way California (INAUDIBLE) and for that I'm very grateful.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

COWAN: And the Federal aid that the President promised to help this community promised to help this community recover is flowing. More than $3-1/2 million is already in the hands of 13,000 households that have registered with FEMA here in Butte County. Those numbers will certainly grow. Lou?

DOBBS: Claudia, thank you very much. Claudia Cowan reporting from Chico, California. Still ahead here tonight, the White House has set new rules of conduct for journalists as the national left-wing media continues to attack President Trump rather than Jim Acosta's conduct.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Jim Acosta's fight for press freedom resulted in a resounding victory for the first amendment.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The system worked tax and balances worked.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Having the press in the White House is actually more of it benefits the White House. So maybe the Trump administration is a little worried about cutting off that tool.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is a about a slippery slope. This is about what other reporters can be talking about this White House.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I don't even think Donald Trump understands the definition of decorum.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are watching the radioholic president at a point of his greatest rage and who it's at and his greatest rage is at the press.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We'll take that up with attorneys Harmeet Dhillon and Gregg Jarrett. But up next, new science that tariffs on Chinese exports to the United States are working and working very well. Asia expert Gordon Chang joins me to talk about the President's winning strategy and the threat of communist China when we continue. Stay with us.

DOBBS: A new report that demonstrates clearly President Trump is succeeding in making China pay for most of the trade tariffs. European researchers now saying American consumers and companies are absorbing only 4-1/2 percent of those tariffs of the 25 percent imposed on $250 billion of Chinese goods. The remaining 80 percent of those tariffs are being paid by China. And joining me now to talk about the very tense U.S.-China relationship and one that doesn't seem to be improving, Gordon Chang.

Author of the Coming Collapse of China and the Nuclear Showdown. Gordon, good to have you here. And welcome back from Tokyo. Good to -- good to see you. But let's start with first these targeted tariffs that the President has implemented and more to follow if the Chinese do not come to their senses. I mean, this has to shock places like Goldman Sachs and the establishment forces that have been lobbying and against these tariffs. Your thoughts?

GORDON CHANG, AMERICAN COLUMNIST: All the smart people who talks about how the American consumer was going to be the one paying for all the tariffs. Well, they are wrong and this is because the administration obviously picked out those areas where there was a lot of elasticity and that's good. You know, the important thing is that --

DOBBS: There goes Gordon using economics where I was just saying today, very few people talk about the elasticity that is the ability to substitute goods or to delay purchasing based on price.

CHANG: Yes. The important thing here is that when you look at the broader picture of the tariffs and the other things that the Trump administration is doing he is actually encouraging supply chains to get out of China. And that's important for us because those supply chains are held hostage by Beijing. Whenever they get upset about something and it's often not about trade, they go against our companies.

DOBBS: And sometimes we use the word -- the word supply chain are used too liberally when the word really is production of products themselves in China. And a dependence upon China for that production. That's got to change obviously as you say. Some other things have got to change. One is it's a communist government, they have expansionist and that's being kind. They have -- they have colonial it seems at times but certainly imperial -- imperatives within their foreign policy that they seem to be shocked that American president would resist as this one has.

CHANG: Yes. Well, Xi Jinping for more than a decade has been dropping hints that China is the world's only sovereign state. And this is just -- basically what he saying is that Americans, Japanese, whatever, you know, are just mere subjects to the greater glory of the Chinese court. You know, the important thing for us is that those trade that we have, you know, our factories in China are producing profits that China is then using to put into its military which is configuring itself to fight Americans.

And so there is a long chain here and it's not just economics, it's also of course security because China needs an enemy and they've identified us.

DOBBS: Well, they've identified us. We should have been too hard to spot because we are the only superpower in the world. This is a -- this is a country under this president that is not recognizable to the power structure in Beijing, is it?

CHANG: No. One thing that President Trump has done especially this year is he's taken actions to defend the American economy. Defend the American society. Chinese leaders don't how to deal with it. So they try to talk to Henry Kissinger, they go try to talk to the heads of financial companies. And --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: The establishment, Wall Street -- Wall Street has been carrying out what the Vice President referred to as lobbying exercise, calling Wall Street and American CEOs participating in the Chinese call for discussions and talks unregistered foreign agents. And my god, that's exactly what they are and kudos to the Vice President for saying it exactly the way it is.

CHANG: Yes. And you know, we saw that September 16th meeting in Beijing before the midterms. Obviously the Chinese were trying to use the heads of the big financial --

DOBBS: They still are.

CHANG: -- against the United States and it didn't work. And right now, the people in Beijing are scratching their head.

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: It hasn't worked so far only because the CEOs didn't take them up on the offer. But they dispatch their minions from the -- in some cases from the seed level offices of their banks and firms. You know, this is an ugly thing we're watching. We're watching propaganda being organized against this President's policies. We're watching the establishment, try to subvert the President's policies on China on international trade.

And the idea that this stuff that has been circulating from the establishment whether it's at the Council of Foreign Relations or it's the Chamber of Commerce, Wall Street, you know, we need quick wins here after this -- the midterms. The president's got a quick win. He won the Senate for crying out loud. He is accomplishing more and now they want to try to talk their way, insinuate themselves into this President's administration and to get him to -- in some cases dilute or even abandon policies that are -- that are certain to be effective.

CHANG: You know, the most important thing here is that these tariffs that people talked about, that are imposed under Section 301 of Trade Act of 1974 as a remedy for the theft of intellectual property. The NSA last week just came out with a report said China's theft of U.S. I.P. for commercial purposes has actually increased over the last year. We saw that report a couple days --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: When is the last time you heard one of the front companies being shut down by either the FBI or any intelligence operation of this agency of this country? You haven't. You haven't heard -- we know that for years they have been operating, literally thousands of front companies working through our universities as well to what? Gather intellectual property by the hundreds of billions of dollars they steal a -- every year.

CHANG: We just got that report that Micron Technology, their most recent chip has been completely stolen by the Chinese. That was $8.95 billion worth of I.P., just one theft and it's occurring across the board, Lou.

DOBBS: And these idiots -- and I will call them what they, they're traitors to the United States. Every one of these people trying to reverse this President's policies, vis-a-vis, Beijing are betraying this country and they're doing so for the -- the most sorted of reasons and that is their own commercial interests. Gordon, great to see. Thanks for being here.

CHANG: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: As always. Gordon Chang. Be sure to vote in our poll tonight. The question is, do you believe communist China finally comprehends President Trump's America First trade policies and demand for balance to free trade -- fair trade? And then into China's theft of U.S. technology is now nonnegotiable. Cast your vote on Twitter @LouDobbs, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs as always, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

Up next, the White House unveiling a new code of conduct for the White House press corps. Oh, that's going to make a few of them very uncomfortable. Journalists with the national left-wing media must act like adults. You think they can do that? Is this a fair set of guidelines? We take that and more right after the break. Harmeet Dhillon and Gregg Jarrett join me. Stay with us. We'll be right back.

DOBBS: The White House today outlining new rules for presidential news conference. The White House has dropped its effort to remove the hard pass of CNN reporter, Jim Acosta. The rules include limiting journalists to one question each, follow-ups at the discretion of the President. And the letter warn, should you refuse to follow these rules in the future, we will take action.

Well, joining me now to take up all of this, the fight over the acting attorney general and more Harmeet Dhillon, attorney, RNC Committeewoman for the great State of California. Great to have you with us. Gregg Jarrett, Fox Legal Analyst, author of the New York Times best-selling, the Russia Hoax. And always good to have you with us. Harmeet, let me begin with you. These rules tonight and if we could let's put those up full-screen just for a second.

These look pretty simple, straightforward, does this meet the test of due process that Judge Kelly asserted?

HARMEET DHILLON, RNC CHAIRWOMAN: Well, it's step one in the due process. First, you have to have the rules announced in advance and then you have to have a warning and notice an opportunity to be heard in response. So, I do think it satisfies the due process and now it remains to be seen whether Acosta is going to carry out his part which is either behaving or being able to justify his actions.

And if he chose the line as a result of this and everybody will be better off and, you know, we won't have anything to worry about. But if he doesn't or somebody else doesn't, then yes, the White House has the right to institute proceedings, give them an opportunity to respond and then take a final action.

DOBBS: Your thoughts.

GREGG JARRETT, FOX BUSINESS LEGAL ANALYST: There have always been rules of decency and decorum that White House correspondents have always practiced when I was there temporarily. I knew the rules, I abided by the rules. Then it comes along guys like Jim Acosta. And they think they have the right to be rude and abrasive and obnoxious and commandeer the news conference and argue with the President and prevent his colleagues from posing their questions.

DOBBS: You have to believe that they are a little upset, the White House press corps that he has messed it up.

JARRETT: Yes. And if I were press secretary, what I would do is the next time Acosta pulls that I would say that's the end of the news conference, not only today but for the rest of the week.

DOBBS: That's what the President said he will do.

JARRETT: And the -- his colleagues, Acosta's colleagues would have surrounded him and threatened to tar and feather and then kick him out. And that is the most effective --

(CROSSTALK)

JARRETT: -- get rid of that kind of conduct. You know --

DOBBS: I mean, let's be honest here, I want to ask you both. Why -- Isn't there a time where you have to just tell a district court judge to go to hell? Because I mean, the idea that you have to follow the dicta of a district court judge and create rules and can't run the White House that it's been run since time (INAUDIBLE) Harmeet?

DHILLON: Well, Lou, to be -- to be fair to the judge, if you read his ruling from the bench, it seems clear that he felt that he was constrained by a prior decision.

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: Yes, but that's (INAUDIBLE) nonsense. That was a 1977 -- excuse me Harmeet that was an idiot in my opinion ruling.

DHILLON: OK.

DOBBS: This judge took a case in which you're dealing with a nation reporter. It wasn't about anything but his politics, it had nothing to do with conduct, it had nothing to do with decorum. And disrupting a presidential press conference, it wasn't on point at all in my opinion. You guys are the lawyer but I mean --

DHILLON: Right. Well, your question -- yes, your question was should we tell the judge to go to hell and the answer is that's generally not a good idea. And I do think that norms announced in advance even though they're obvious like, you know, you shouldn't have to tell people to behave like adults but now that we have that, well, I think it's actually a good --

DOBBS: You shouldn't have to tell a district court judge to get back on your -- get back on your bailiwick either, what do you think?

DHILLON: Well, on the other --

JARRETT: Wait, you're absolutely right. When you are of -- there's no freedom to be obnoxious and rude, there's no freedom of the press to question the president. It's a privilege to be there at the White House and there are rules and norms that have always been followed. And now you've got a judge who has decided to expand due process beyond any resemblance --

DOBBS: He's telling the president of the United States how to conduct the --

JARRETT: And I agree with you, I would tell the judge go to hell. We're going to practice the way we want. Let the Supreme Court decide it if necessary.

DOBBS: Let me turn very quickly to the president prepared to give his written answers to Robert Mueller. Let's take his comments to Chris Wallace yesterday, if we could please.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The questions were asked and answered, wasn't a big deal. You know, they make it like I had meetings for many, many hours. I got the questions, I responded, we wrote them out, I read them once, I read them a second time we made some changes, that's it. I think that should solve the problem. I hope itself is a problem, if it doesn't, you know, I'll be told and we'll make a decision at that time but probably this is the end.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: There's the president Harmeet, is this the end in your best judgment?

DHILLON: Well, I think it should be the end from the president's side. I think this is handled correctly and this is the extent of his involvement in this now. Who knows what Mueller is going to do with this and there may be a second round. This may attempt to go on forever but I hope for that this puts an end. Arrest and this is the appropriate way to handle it, given how busy the president is.

DOBBS: Gregg?

JARRETT: With obstruction off the table, it should've taken five minutes to answer the questions. I don't know anything about collusion, I don't know anybody else in my campaign who knew or colluded with Russia, end of story. And you can dismiss allegations of the Trump Tower meeting. Did Trump know in advance? I did not he said that repeatedly. Did you mislead anyone in your dictated statement it was accurate to the best of my knowledge. So, I mean, those are the main questions they should be easy to answer.

DOBBS: And after over two years of investigating this president and his administration, enough is enough, it's enough. It's actually far more than enough.

JARRETT: Right.

DOBBS: Harmeet Dhillon, Gregg Jarrett thank you both for being with us tonight, thank you.

DHILLON: Thanks Lou.

DOBBS: Up next, after nearly two weeks, the results are settled in Florida. It's up two victories -- two victories for the President and the Republicans, the Senate majority for the Republicans is growing. We take that up and more with the dynamic duo, Diamond and Silk joining us tonight. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

DOBBS: On Wall Street today a big sell-off. The Dow losing almost 400 points, the S&P lost 46, the NASDAQ down 219. Volume on the big board 3.7 billion shares.

Facebook, Apple, Netflix, Google parent Alphabet all dropping into bear market territory closing out the day. Facebook's stock plummeted heading in -- heading into 2019. The company's stock losing five percent hitting its lowest level since February of 2017. Facebook on track for its longest quarterly loss to --losing streak since 2013.

Apple CEO Tim Cook weighing in on the possibility that Congress will regulate big tech, here he is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: Generally speaking, I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market. But we have to admit when the free markets not working and it hasn't worked here and I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: The president has said as much. The president making it very clear that he is not thrilled with monopolistic powers or the oligopolies that have formed in technology.

A reminder listened to my reports three times a day coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Embattled controversial election supervisor. A Broward CountyFlorida has produced a suitable ending, Brenda Snipes has resigned. Snipes facing criticism for her failure to comply with Florida law and the 2018 midterms after years of incompetence and skulduggery, President Trump called for her to be fired. Just days ago, her resignation takes effect. Are you ready? She's a lame-duck. Her resignation effective in January taking a page out of -- well, someone we all knows book.

Joining me now, social media superstars, President Trump's most loyal supporters, Diamond and Silk. Great to have you with us. Let me start by asking you, will there be now national left-wing media focus on the fact this president has achieved a terrific victory for the U.S. Senate enlarging the GOP majority?

LYNNETTE HARDAWAY, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITIES, DIAMOND AND SILK: It should be, they should focus on that, but you know they're not. What they will focus on the left-wing media is start throwing the racist word around or this is racist or somebody as being racist towards me. I absolutely love and I'm so thrilled that Brenda Snipe's out. Was that she's stepping down.

ROCHELLE RICHARDSON, SOCIAL MEDIA PERSONALITIES, DIAMOND AND SILK: Yes.

HARDAWAY: She should have been fired a long time ago. Because if you look at what she did in this whole process is what they were trying to do. They were -- they were doing a rehearsal getting prepared for the 2020 run.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: It was going to be the art of the steal and I want everybody. I don't care what's on the aisle you're on to look at that. When you break our election laws and do what you want to and not answer questions that should be answered.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: You're trying to take something you're trying to steal but she should have been fired a long time ago.

DOBBS: You know governor elect DeSantis saying that there was no way that she was going to be the election supervisor through another election. I'm amazed that they put up with the shenanigans and being very kind. The cheating and the stealing in that elections office as long as they did.

The White House press corps let's turn their, new rules. We can call them the -- I don't know what the Acosta rules. I don't know what you would want to call them, in which the whole press corps gets to ask one question, they've got to be civil and they've got to be kind of focused on their manners. What do you think?

HARDAWAY: Well, listen, I absolutely love it. I think Acosta if he wants to be respected as a journalist, he have to respect the White House and respect the president.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: He's going to have to do that. No more acting like a baby, no more wanting to suck on your pacifier. We're not going to put you on timeout. If you do, if you defy the rules --

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: -- you're going to get thrown out, not a timeout but up at that White House and your press conditions are going to be taken again.

RICHARDSON: So, the bottom line is this Lou, if you act like a child you would be treated like a child, bottom line.

DOBBS: And certainly in the presence of the President of the United States and in the White House itself, I would think that would come as second nature to any American.

Let me -- let me turn first to in terms of foreign policy, a president who has introduced the entire country and all of our trading partners to an extraordinary concept. We're going to have balanced trade, you're not going to steal from us by the hundreds of billions of dollars a year anymore. Specifically that case obviously fits China. They're behaving like children, they want to be able to keep stealing and they think that we should be subsidizing their economy and buying their products no matter what the impact is on our workers and our corporations. Your thoughts about the Chinese having just a bit of a fit over this insistence by the president.

HARDAWAY: Well, they're going to have to stop having this little hissy fit.

RICHARDSON: That's right.

HARDAWAY: Because you have a new sheriff in town, its President Donald Trump and he's a businessman and it's going to be fair and equal trade across the board. You're not going to steal from us and they're going to have to get that through their head. And President Trump is not going to waver nor is he going to back down. I know that they're used to dealing with weak presidents like President Obama and the rest of them.

RICHARDSON: Yes.

HARDAWAY: But you have a strong president that's not going to tolerate.

RICHARDSON: And you have a strong president that's putting American first baby. It's about America because charity starts at home not abroad.

DOBBS: Thank you so much for being with us. It's always great to see you my friends. Thanks so much Diamond and Silk.

HARDAWAY: Thanks for having us.

DOBBS: All the best. Well, Pope Francis dining with 1,500 people, poor people in the Vatican over the weekend. And there, he decried the plight of the indigent. As he addressed the crowd of Francis lamented the poor are weeping quote, while the wealthy few feast on what injustice belongs to all. Injustice is the perverse root of poverty.

Up next, there could be fewer U.S. troops along our southern border with Mexico. Are you ready for this already? We're hearing from a general about troop levels. The caravan has arrived in Tijuana. Thousands more expected, what is going on? We take up these latest developments with The Daily Caller's Vince Coglianese when we return. Stay with us.

DOBBS: The Pentagon may begin scaling back the troops posted along our border with Mexico as early as this week. The army commander overseeing the mission Lieutenant General Jeffrey Buchanan telling Politico the missions end date remains December 15th that all of the active duty troops who were sent to the border could be home by Christmas despite the expected arrival of thousands more in caravans at the southern border in the days and weeks ahead.

According to a new poll from Monmouth University, more than half of Americans see the migrant caravans moving toward the country as a threat to the United States. In the poll released today nearly a third of them see the caravans is a major threat. And the same poll found seven and ten Americans see illegal immigration as a serious issue. Joining us tonight to discuss the caravan, Jim Acosta's new rules, and the sore losers in the Democratic Party, the Daily Callers Editorial Director Vince Coglianese. It's good to have you with us, Vince.

VINCE COGLIANESE, EDITORIAL DIRECTOR, DAILY CALLERS: Nice to be here, Lou. Thank you.

DOBBS: Let us start with this unexpected announcement that troops may apparently be withdrawn very quickly from the border.

COGLIANESE: Yes, I think -- I thought an underlying principle of the Trump administration is that we don't broadcast our intentions with our military ahead of time. We have to keep people guessing for national security reasons and that's not what's happening here. I think what you're pointing out is that it's a bit of a bizarre messaging to say hey the troops are going to be away from the border by Christmas. And if you are the -- if you're looking to illegally immigrate into the United States, you now have a great time lined by which to do that. So that's -- I think that's a bit uninspired to be giving those sorts of answers whether or not you intend to actually do it.

DOBBS: This lieutenant general who I haven't heard of before but that doesn't mean anything necessarily, had to surely understand this is a political question of great sensitivity and that he would be very wise indeed to not speak to it without White House approval, in fact insisting I would think for his own career that it come from the White House.

COGLIANESE: It was clearly an issue of sincere concern of the President of the United States so that would be my first thought too, what does the White House think of this, the statement I'm about to make. And I think what you're seeing if I'm just making a prediction here holding on my finger at the wind, it looks like the military is succumbing a bit to the liberal media pressure on this question. This idea -- you saw the New York Times run this big story. The troops are out there. They're going to miss holidays. They signed up to defend our country. They signed up for our national security. And one of the paramount concerns is the integrity of our borders.

These men and women on the border doing the job they were asked to do by their Commander-in-Chief and yet the New York Times is coming at it from the perspective of how dare they even be a part of this and I think the military is coming to that a little bit by broadcasting this idea that oh don't worry, everyone will be home by Christmas. There won't be military on the border to assist the border patrol. Not a good message to send when you have so many illegal immigrants knocking on the door.

DOBBS: No matter what, there's a serious problem in the Pentagon because once again Mattis, the Defense Secretary is putting himself in at this point what appears to be opposition to the Commander in Chief. Indeed a stunning stuff to witness.

COGLIANESE: And General Mattis went to the border this week with Kirstjen Nielsen this past week to actually survey the activity of the troops. It's nice to see him out there. I think that's a good thing encouraging the troops, and that's -- and that's the key here. And look, the reason those troops are on the border is to assist the Border Patrol in its very tall task. I mean, you look at this migrant caravan that's standing in Tijuana right now, that is not even the start of it. Think back to October. You know this really well, Lou. Nearly 60,000 people were arrested or turned back at the border with the United States in Mexico. That's a record. And that means that this migrant crisis is continuing every day. Caravans, forget caravans. We have a caravan coming every day into the United States of America.

DOBBS: And let me turn to the White House since we're on that subject, and that is the new rules announced by Sarah Sanders today, the new rules for journalists in the White House press corps.

COGLIANESE: Yes.

DOBBS: One question, you know, behave yourself, we'll see how things go is my summation. Your reaction to these new Acosta rules.

COGLIANESE: Look, that's the key. That's the key right there. This is Jim Acosta's fault. The reality is, if you're a member of that press corps, if you're in that White House press briefing room, yes, of course, you're standing up alongside your fellow reporter arguing for the most amount of times ask questions that you can possibly get. But here's the key. Jim Acosta, by virtue of the debate he held with the President of the United States, not questioning a debate. He started to -- he started out by saying he wanted to challenge the President on a talking point. That's not the role.

The role is to get information out of the president for the American people and he failed in that core test. And in so doing, he made it worse for the entire press corps because now they have restrictive rules on their ability to ask follow-up questions, all courtesy of one man Jim Acosta.

DOBBS: Well, one man and one organization. Then you go to Jeff Zucker at CNN, then you go to the parent Time-Warner, and then you go to the parent of the parent which is AT&T. And the reality is we're watching corporate behemoth direct the conduct that of a Jim Acosta.

COGLIANESE: Yes.

DOBBS: There's a purpose in it and no one should mistake that. We're watching Comcast when it comes to NBC. I mean, it goes on and on. These are corporate, corporate journalists behaving that way. Obviously at the direction of their corporations.

COGLIANESE: Well, if you want you want to do something fun or if your viewers ever want to basically take a look at like how that White House press briefing room was actually composed and who gets paid by whom in that room, look no further than the first couple rows. Fox has a couple of reporters by virtue of Fox News radio and Fox News and Fox Business, of course. But those are individual networks. What you have in that room are Washington Post reporters, New York Times reporters. The first couple rows, they're all paid by CNN and MSNBC. They're paid contributors to those networks. In other words, those two lefty networks have control, are paying a huge percentage of the major figures who were that press briefing. That is a very real conflict of interest.

DOBBS: Conflict of interest and one you would think that the White House would want to examine very carefully. You know, the issue of Acosta, the CNN, you know, I just have to think that the White House press corps is beside itself with these rules coming down all because of the way Acosta behaved and you know, did so with you know, I mean it just doesn't make any sense to me.

COGLIANESE: Unquestionably. But one of the lessons I take from this is like the seething hatred for the Trump White House must be so great in that room that they're willing to tolerate the insanity of Jim Acosta which strikes me as the most bizarre thing ever. At some point, they have to tap out in the go, you know what, Jim Acosta, you are poorly serving our ability to actually ask questions of the White House.

DOBBS: And I don't suppose that would be possibly a part of the White House strategy to make certain that they become self-policing and self- aware. Vince Coglianese, great to have you with us. Thanks so much.

COGLIANESE: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next, more on the migrant Caravan as they find out what happens in Tijuana, the Mexican people weren't too thrilled with them and they are the ones protesting illegal immigrants not on this side of the border. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

DOBBS: Last week we asked you if you believe President Trump's border wall will ever be built? 67 percent of you said yes, and the rest, no. Well, here's where we are tonight, what we're looking at tomorrow. The migrant caravan in Tijuana now is facing such opposition from angry local residents there reporting this fights in rocks hurl. The Department of Homeland Security also says at least 500 people, 500 of them criminals have been identified within the caravan.

Brenda Snipes, the Broward County Florida election supervisor is -- she's submitted her resignation. Over the last two weeks she's been responsible for misplacing if you will, 2,000 ballots, counting those ballots, mixing invalid ballots with good ones, failing to meet a deadline with machine recount results altering the outcome of course of the recount, and in fact, disqualifying it.

That's it for us tonight. Tomorrow night, please be with us. We'll see you then. Good night from New York.

urn:contentItem:5TSP-K701-JBHT-D2PY-00000-00Migrant Caravan At U.S. Border Is Harboring More Than 500 Criminals, Homeland Security Claims; White House Drops Effort To Suspend Press Pass For CNN's Jim Acosta; Report: President Donald Trump To Submit Written Answers To Bob Mueller Questions By Thanksgiving; Broward County Election Supervisor Brenda Snipes Resigns After Recount; RPT: Pentagon To Begin Troop Drawback From U.S. Southern Border2018-11-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisMigrant Caravan At U.S. Border Is Harboring More Than 500 Criminals, Homeland Security Claims; White House Drops Effort To Suspend Press Pass For CNN's Jim Acosta; Report: President Donald Trump To Submit Written Answers To Bob Mueller Questions By Thanksgiving; Broward County Election Supervisor Brenda Snipes Resigns After Recount; RPT: Pentagon To Begin Troop Drawback From U.S. Southern BorderLanhamFULL TEXT

(CROSSTALK)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Thank you for having us in your home. Guys, I love this squad over there. Thank you for watching. Lou Dobbs is next right here on the Fox Business Network. Have a good night.

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening, everybody. Our top stories, tensions between the United States and China escalating as President Trump and his administration insist on America First foreign policy that includes fair trade, balance trade and respect for the U.S. and U.S. property throughout the world. China's president Xi Jinping and Vice President Mike Pence delivered dueling speeches in Asia over the weekend.

Presenting two very different views of global trade and security. We take that up, we discuss the latest in the U.S.-China relationship. China expert Gordon Chang with us. Also tonight, more in rest in Tijuana as Central American migrants are clashing with hundreds of local Mexican residents who don't want them in their city. President Trump remaining steadfast in his commitment to strong borders warning those in the caravan not to try to enter, not to try to enter the United States illegally.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're not letting people in to our country illegally. And we're not doing a release. We'll do a catch but we're not doing releases. So, if they think they're going to be released into our country like in the old days, like for years and years they catch and release, we're not releasing. They don't get released.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: We take up the latest in the situation south of our border. Fox Reporter William La Jeunesse, is reporting tonight from Tijuana and The Daily Caller's Vince Coglianese join us. In California, 80 are dead, nearly 1000 people are still missing as the deadliest fire in the state's history continue to burn ahead of an expected rainstorm. We'll have the latest from California, tonight.

Our top story, drop in the shares of Apple. Another big tech fueling a big selloff on Wall Street today. The Dow Jones Industrial is down almost 400 points. The S&P 500 down 46, the NASDAQ lost more than 200 points. And amidst of the market turmoil, the White House continuing to demand fair trade policies from China ahead of an upcoming meeting that will take place between the President and Xi Jinping at the end of this month.

Edward Lawrence in Washington with the story. Edward?

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINES NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Lou. Trade fair is part of that market drop. The breaking news tonight, the state department spokeswoman reacted to harsh language by the Chinese without mentioning China following the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit. Now, the statement tonight reads, the United States is proud to agree to promote free and fair trade in the region and combat unfair trade practices.

It is unfortunate that not all economies despite their rhetoric could support these positions. And the cooperation summit fail to issue a joint statement for the first time in 29 years. The China blames the U.S. for spoiling the summit. A spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry saying, it seem like the U.S. attended this APEC meeting with great anger. Speeches and remarks at the meeting openly cause controversy, created discourse, spilling the atmosphere -- or spoiling the atmosphere of the meeting and did not contribute to achieving consensus.

Well, the Vice President brief the President today. This summit seem to escalate the trade dispute towards a trade war as China continues with their trading practices. They are not changing. The Chinese delegation led Vice-Premier supposed to meet in Washington this week, they canceled again. These were prep talks related to the G27 Summit bilateral meeting between President Xi Jinping and President Donald Trump.

The Chinese say the meeting will happen after the bilateral on December 1st, assuming it goes well. Now, former FTC Chairman under President Reagan says, China should not underestimate President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: No matter what, there's a serious problem in the Pentagon because once again Mattis, the Defense Secretary is putting himself in at this point what appears to be opposition to the Commander in Chief. Indeed a stunning stuff to witness.

COGLIANESE: And General Mattis went to the border this week with Kirstjen Nielsen this past week to actually survey the activity of the troops. It's nice to see him out there. I think that's a good thing encouraging the troops, and that's -- and that's the key here. And look, the reason those troops are on the border is to assist the Border Patrol in its very tall task. I mean, you look at this migrant caravan that's standing in Tijuana right now, that is not even the start of it. Think back to October. You know this really well, Lou. Nearly 60,000 people were arrested or turned back at the border with the United States in Mexico. That's a record. And that means that this migrant crisis is continuing every day. Caravans, forget caravans. We have a caravan coming every day into the United States of America.

DOBBS: And let me turn to the White House since we're on that subject, and that is the new rules announced by Sarah Sanders today, the new rules for journalists in the White House press corps.

COGLIANESE: Yes.

DOBBS: One question, you know, behave yourself, we'll see how things go is my summation. Your reaction to these new Acosta rules.

COGLIANESE: Look, that's the key. That's the key right there. This is Jim Acosta's fault. The reality is, if you're a member of that press corps, if you're in that White House press briefing room, yes, of course, you're standing up alongside your fellow reporter arguing for the most amount of times ask questions that you can possibly get. But here's the key. Jim Acosta, by virtue of the debate he held with the President of the United States, not questioning a debate. He started to -- he started out by saying he wanted to challenge the President on a talking point. That's not the role.

The role is to get information out of the president for the American people and he failed in that core test. And in so doing, he made it worse for the entire press corps because now they have restrictive rules on their ability to ask follow-up questions, all courtesy of one man Jim Acosta.

DOBBS: Well, one man and one organization. Then you go to Jeff Zucker at CNN, then you go to the parent Time-Warner, and then you go to the parent of the parent which is AT&T. And the reality is we're watching corporate behemoth direct the conduct that of a Jim Acosta.

COGLIANESE: Yes.

DOBBS: There's a purpose in it and no one should mistake that. We're watching Comcast when it comes to NBC. I mean, it goes on and on. These are corporate, corporate journalists behaving that way. Obviously at the direction of their corporations.

COGLIANESE: Well, if you want you want to do something fun or if your viewers ever want to basically take a look at like how that White House press briefing room was actually composed and who gets paid by whom in that room, look no further than the first couple rows. Fox has a couple of reporters by virtue of Fox News radio and Fox News and Fox Business, of course. But those are individual networks. What you have in that room are Washington Post reporters, New York Times reporters. The first couple rows, they're all paid by CNN and MSNBC. They're paid contributors to those networks. In other words, those two lefty networks have control, are paying a huge percentage of the major figures who were that press briefing. That is a very real conflict of interest.

DOBBS: Conflict of interest and one you would think that the White House would want to examine very carefully. You know, the issue of Acosta, the CNN, you know, I just have to think that the White House press corps is beside itself with these rules coming down all because of the way Acosta behaved and you know, did so with you know, I mean it just doesn't make any sense to me.

COGLIANESE: Unquestionably. But one of the lessons I take from this is like the seething hatred for the Trump White House must be so great in that room that they're willing to tolerate the insanity of Jim Acosta which strikes me as the most bizarre thing ever. At some point, they have to tap out in the go, you know what, Jim Acosta, you are poorly serving our ability to actually ask questions of the White House.

DOBBS: And I don't suppose that would be possibly a part of the White House strategy to make certain that they become self-policing and self- aware. Vince Coglianese, great to have you with us. Thanks so much.

COGLIANESE: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Up next, more on the migrant Caravan as they find out what happens in Tijuana, the Mexican people weren't too thrilled with them and they are the ones protesting illegal immigrants not on this side of the border. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DOBBS: Last week we asked you if you believe President Trump's border wall will ever be built? 67 percent of you said yes, and the rest, no. Well, here's where we are tonight, what we're looking at tomorrow. The migrant caravan in Tijuana now is facing such opposition from angry local residents there reporting this fights in rocks hurl. The Department of Homeland Security also says at least 500 people, 500 of them criminals have been identified within the caravan.

Brenda Snipes, the Broward County Florida election supervisor is -- she's submitted her resignation. Over the last two weeks she's been responsible for misplacing if you will, 2,000 ballots, counting those ballots, mixing invalid ballots with good ones, failing to meet a deadline with machine recount results altering the outcome of course of the recount, and in fact, disqualifying it.

That's it for us tonight. Tomorrow night, please be with us. We'll see you then. Good night from New York.

END
