BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Adrienne Elrod, Marc Lotter, good to see you both. Thank you very much --

LOTTER: Thank you.

ELROD: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: for weighing in on all of this. By the way, the President has said (INAUDIBLE) he's not going to fire Robert Mueller. So I don't know why, you know, this question keeps coming up.

MCDOWELL: Because the, media, every time that he is near a microphone, people are shouting the question at him, are you going to fire Bob Mueller? Are you going to fire Bob Mueller? So this is an idea, looking at it from my perspective, they are goading him.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It says if members of the media are goading him to fire Bob Mueller. And it's -- you know what it had? It's a narrative that's basically concocted by people --

BARTIROMO: Muddy the waters. Keep money in the waters. All right, coming up, China's largest ride-hailing company, reportedly revving up its IPO plans, the jaw-dropping valuation for the company, coming up. And then Krispy Kreme celebrates spring with a limited-edition donut, but you have to act fast for this tasty treat. Plus, two big interviews, coming up, Senator Rand Paul and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, join me later on in the program. Back in a moment, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news overnight, a major Chinese ride hailing company reportedly gears up for a multibillion-dollar IPO. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Multi-billion, Maria. Get this, the Wall Street Journal says the DiDi Chuxing is in talks with bankers about going public; possible valuation up to $80 billion. The offering could happen as soon as this year, and that cash will be used for DiDi to expand internationally. If this company went public, DiDi would beat rival Uber to the public markets.

Privacy concerns hitting Match.com users after a glitch re-activated some old accounts. And while the company maintained, it was a limited number of accounts, their current privacy statements says that the company can retain certain information associated with your account even after you close it, even if you get married, have children, there you go. Old accounts are reactivated if you see a password reset e-mail for Match, you don't have an account any more there were go. Match landed in 1995, they're now available in 25 countries. Shares of match grew; actually, up about 50 percent so far this year.

OK, Maria, you may remember we reported on this, there was a big contest to name the next Krispy Kreme donut flavor. A lot of strong opinion on set that day. Two million votes came in and the winner is lemon glaze. Lemon beat out blueberry, caramel, and maple. I know -- I wanted maple. The new donut goes on sale today; only for a week -- whatever, Krispy Kreme. It's only available through Sunday. I forgot who wanted lemon. I was voting for maple, but there was a lot of back and forth on that one. BARTIROMO: You wanted lemon.

BRENBERG: Lemon is the rightful winner here. There's nothing better on a donut than lemon glaze.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon --

BRENBERG: Way better than maple.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon, talk about Uber, they can't even get their IPO out, their valuations gone to $46 billion. The Chinese company, they had to cede control too in China. Now, valued at 80 billion, can you believe it? That's a lemon.

BARTIROMO: Will Uber ever go public.

KELLY: Yes, yes, yes. Their CEO has re-affirmed that they are going to go public in 2019.

MCDOWELL: I've got my head on my hands because some the mornings, you just want to talk about donuts, Kevin. Some morning --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: All business all the time. That's it.

MCDOWELL: You know what, he's our younger brother. And I just have to bust your job. I can't help it. You're my younger brother too.

BRENBERG: The donut eating and talking younger brother.

MCDOWELL: You understand the importance of talking about it?

BRENBERG: Priorities in life.

KELLY: Yes, but I'm just upset we didn't get maple, that's why, so I had to pivot.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think I'm with you on the maple, by the way. Coming up, Mitt Romney's ribbing -- did you see it? Former presidential candidate getting into playoff fever last night with courtside tots during the Utah Jazz playoff game. And forget sports drinks and shoe endorsements, Steph Curry has just landed a major entertainment deal. Sports is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. In the NBA Playoffs, the Houston Rockets are soaring to new heights. Jared Max with all the details. Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Houston, Minnesota has a problem. James Harden pumped the Rocket fuel in the second quarter like the team have never seen. Game three Rockets-Timberwolves. Houston up two games to one. Harden scores 22 points in the second quarter, 22 of the Rockets, 50. One point off the NBA record set 56 years ago. For the most points in the playoff quarter, Harden finish with 36, Rockets win by 19. They only need one more win to advance Team Wolves free,

Game four in Salt Lake City, between the Jazz and Thunder running for Senate in Utah. Former presidential candidate, Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney taunting, talking trash to OKC star, Russell Westbrook. He keeps holding up his fingers that there's four -- four fouls. Eventually, Russell Westbrook gets his fifth foul and the Jazz win by 17. Donovan Mitchell's scored 33. Utah leads three games to one.

Veteran Bay Area T.V. sport anchor and one-time 49ers Receiver Mike Shumann of KGO T.V. in San Francisco allegedly was caught on video last week in San Antonio appearing to steal a jacket that belonged to the Golden State Warriors Head of Security, Ralph Walker. KGO investigating Shumann, reportedly sent home from NBA Playoff coverage.

Move over Lebron James. You're not the only NBA superstar making waves in the entertainment world. Warriors' great Stephen Curry has chosen Sony Entertainment Pictures after cording with several industry giants to sign what is described as a wide-ranging multi-year deal, unanimous media -- that's the company that Steph created recently. Film, television, electronics gaming, virtual reality, it's all there for Steph whose production lot will be in Culver City at Sony Pictures -- life after basketball.

On one side, we have Rob Gronkowski, the New England Patriots Tight End. And on the other, Rob Gronkowski, just Gronkowski, the 3-year-old cult, named for the Patriots' tight end. Rob Gronkowski, the player, recently bought minority stake in the stakes horse, Gronkowski, who is set to run in next month's Kentucky Derby. But, Gronkowski, the horse, had a spike and fever last weekend, and Gronkowski is not going to be running the Kentucky Derby, and that's going to be May 5th at Churchill Downs. Rob Gronkowski, the person, expressing his lament. Well, I want to know who gets back on the field first: Rob Gronkowski the player or Rob Gronkowski the horse?

KELLY: I think Rob Gronkowski should run the Kentucky Derby, he's the true beast. I bet he could outrun that horse.

MAX: He said he wanted to get on that horse.

KELLY: Oh, he did?

MAX: And that was scary right of at that.

KELLY: Would he do it shirtless?

MAX: I don't know what he'd do, but he's got a four time the body mass of a jockey so.

BARTIROMO: Hey, how about this: racing champ, Matt Kenseth, to make a return to NASCAR, Dagen. Big news for NASCAR.

MCDOWELL: It's kind of an exclamation point on what's been going on in the sport. Matt Kenseth is returning. He's going to part-time drive for Roush Racing this -- the rest of this year. He's spent about a dozen years racing for Roush, that's where he was when he won his only cup championship that was back 2003 before the current playoff series was introduced. Then, he raced for Joe Gibbs racing. Joe Gibbs racing replaced him with the younger cheaper driver, which is a testament to what's happening in the sport, is they want young blood. Again, it's not just the ladies who get cast aside when they get a little bit older, it's the men the too. They want young blood because they think millennials, that will attract to advertising dollars and they're a lot cheaper. So, they're trying to get the salaries down on these drives and attract ads -- attract ad dollars. Matt Kenseth, luckily, is getting back --

KELLY: Is part-time driving, is that a wave of the future? I've never heard really, kind of, part-time.

MCDOWELL: Maybe, I highly doubt it, because it makes it very hard for somebody to race, somebody who's only in the car part of the time. And I think that would impossible for you to -- if you're only racing part-time, impossible to win a championship.

BRENBERG: Kevin, I don't think you can get into it.

KELLY: OK. I've got a day job.

MCDOWELL: Yes, that was it. That was the first sexist comment I've made.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: But I said it, so.

MAX: Hey, how about -- Jenny Cavnar last time, very cool calls of baseball game, play-by-play for the Colorado Rockies' first woman, who 25 years ago.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was cool.

MAX: Cool stuff.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. Catch Jared's sports report Fox News Headlines 24/7 or SiriusXM 115. Still ahead, full steam ahead for phase two of tax reform. Kevin Brady in the studio, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, April 24th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

urn:contentItem:5S64-KB31-JBHT-D1H9-00000-00Mike Pompeo Advances Out Of Committee With Favorable Recommendation, Following Paul Flipping His Vote; Iran To Trump: Stay In Nuclear Deal or 'Face Severe Consequences'; Protests Expected At Wells Fargo Shareholder Meeting Today; Retirement Realities2018-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisMike Pompeo Advances Out Of Committee With Favorable Recommendation, Following Paul Flipping His Vote; Iran To Trump: Stay In Nuclear Deal or 'Face Severe Consequences'; Protests Expected At Wells Fargo Shareholder Meeting Today; Retirement RealitiesLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, April 24th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast, a blue chip earnings blitz today. Six Dow components all reporting their first-quarter earnings before the opening bell. Caterpillar leader the way beating expectations on both profit and revenue while also raising full year guidance. The stock is up. The strong results looking to Dow futures indicating a pretty good rally at the start of trading this morning. This is right around the high of the morning up 150 points on the Dow two-thirds of one percent. S&P is also up two-thirds of a percent as does the NASDAQ for the gain of 38 points right now. Alphabet beating expectations on both profit and revenue last night, but the company is raising concerns about expenses as we expected. The stock is down this morning, one half of one percent in the premarket.

Newer markets closed mostly lower yesterday weighed down by yields -- rising bond yields as the 10 year crept closer to three percent. The DowIndustrials were down 14 points, fractional move on a percentage basis. S&P was up a fraction and the NASDAQ was down about a quarter of a percent, 17 points. The Dow was down for a fourth day in a row. That was the longest losing streak since March. In Europe this morning, the indices look like with the FT-100 showing a gain of 25. The CAC Quarante is up fractionally and the DAX Index is up 28 points. That's a quarter of a percent higher. In Asia overnight, stocks closing mostly higher with the exception of Korea. Best performer was Shanghai in China the top performer up at two percent on the session. In open book for the first time, Facebook is revealing its secret rules for user posts where the company says crosses the line. And then a change of heart, Kentucky Senator Rand Paul reversed his stance and cleared the way for President Trump's Secretary of State nominee, Mike Pompeo.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. RAND PAUL (R-KY), SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE: I've been opposed to this nomination for a long time. I hope that they'll let Trump be Trump and that Pompeo will be a constructive influences and not a destructive one. But from what I've been told and listened to with director I think that he is open and understands that his job is -- that the president is his boss.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I'll speak with the Kentucky Senator Rand Paul coming up about his Pompeo decision. Join us at 8:30 this morning in about 30 minutes for that special interview. And then cashing in on the crypto craze, the details as Goldman Sachs makes its first hire for the cryptocurrency market. All those stories coming up Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network Dagen McDowell, The King's College Business Economics Professor Brian Brenberg, and Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly. Great to see everybody.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Yes. It's great to be here especially during earnings week.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: A third of the S&P reporting earnings this week.

BRIAN BRENBERG, BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR, THE KING'S COLLEGE: And having a little effect today. The Dow is up. There are some good news coming already this morning. Maybe CAC won't dominate the week. Maybe some of these bread and butter companies in the economy will dominate the - -

BARTIROMO: Oh, you got Amazon coming out on Thursday. You got Qualcomm and Intel coming out tomorrow and Thursday.

KELLY: And Pulte actually reported this morning and the home builders are doing exceptionally well. They've consistently beat. There were worries about, you know, with rising interest rates how that's going to affect. But we have a limited supply of housing in the United States here. It's a big over hang and that's why you're seeing the rental markets still do well in face of that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: With home building and construction they'll watch for rising import costs, watch for rising inflation. There were a bunch of stories being passed around last week about condo developers killing projects and say Toronto because of the rising material costs, and that was one of the things that fueled the move out of treasury bonds here I think. And, again, I think that if you -- if you top 30 percent yield on 10 year could be very, very rough going through the stock market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, I don't know why though. I mean -- OK. So it's three percent but you're still talking about rock bottom numbers. I mean why would so afraid three percent.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- worrying about the Federal Reserve overreacting to inflation concerns and they start worrying about you hit three, you start worrying about --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: It's a bigger percentage move to go from two percent to three percent then three percent to four percent. It's actually -- and in an economy that's going to have over three percent GDP growth this year, you look at the nominal grow -- I mean it's unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Again, it's unprecedented unwinding of unprecedented stimulus from our central bank and I don't think anybody knows how that's going to end.

BARTIROMO: How many people have come on this program and said to us the biggest risk to economic growth right now is the Federal Reserve?

MCDOWELL: Right.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: We talked about it in last year.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Big conversation this morning about all of the above. Joining the conversation Kentucky Senator and Foreign Relations Committee member Rand Paul is with me today. I will get his take on his last minute reversal to vote in favor of Mike Pompeo for Secretary of State, the budget, and a lot more. Don't miss that special interview coming up. But first is our top story is earnings in focus, six Dow companies are reporting earnings this morning including Travelers, 3M, Coca-Cola. They had mixed reports overall. But United Technologies, Caterpillar, and Verizon all beat on earnings and revenue for the first quarter and all of those stocks are trading higher. Caterpillar was one that was really closely watched because that is a big indicator of global economic activity. Futures right now indicating a big gain at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up 150 points right out of the gate, two- thirds of one percent. The NASDAQ is up half a percent right now, 35 points higher. And joining us right now to talk more about all that is The Gartman Letter Editor and Publisher Dennis Gartman. Dennis, good to see you sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

DENNIS GARTMAN, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER, THE GARTMAN LETTER: Always honored to be on. Thanks for asking me.

BARTIROMO: Before we get to the fundamentals if you will in terms of earnings, let's talk technical because I know you like to look at the charts. What do the charts tell you right now, Dennis, in terms of where we are in the stock market rally?

GARTMAN: I think it's -- it bothers me greatly that we have seen the highs. I'm quite convince in both the market here in the United States and globally, so I'm actually in the long-term quite bearish of equities, I think that we've got the monetary authorities here in the United States already erring upon the side of tighter monetary policy. We've seen the adjusted monetary based on about 10 percent from its highs. That's not going to change anytime soon. We're allowing the monetary base to roll off. We're probably going to see the ECB begin to tighten. The only bank of consequence that won't be tightening the monetary policy anytime soon is the Bank of Japan and as long as the monetary authority is on balance are beginning that process they're taking away the liquidity that has sponsored the Bull market. So technically, I'm actually quite bearish. In the short run, we got so terribly oversold two weeks ago that we're having a good bounce. We shouldn't be surprised by this, but if we took the Dow up another 150 to 200, I guarantee you I shall be selling.

BARTIROMO: Let's not forget though that there's this narrative right now that things aren't going to slow down. Dagen, they've got this massive balance to walk the Federal Reserve does. Even Robert Kaplan from the Dallas Federal Reserve last week said, he wants this two more rate hikes a total of three for this year because while he's expecting 2.6 percent or 2.7 percent growth this year, he thinks growth plummets down to one and three-quarters percent by the end of '19, so there's this narrative that things are going to start slowing down in a big way.

MCDOWELL: And that's something -- that echoes how Stephanie Pomboy has felt about this economy. But to -- what we're talking about the Federal Reserve winding down that balance sheet, that's -- they've laid out a plan to do that. And it would require something really extreme and dramatic in the economy for them to change course at this point on that note. And I don't think people really understand what this economy looks like with the markets look like without all of that buying by Federal Reserve, and one thing I would just point out and it's to kind of pivot a little bit but watch these NAFTA negotiations to sort of going on. They resumed today behind closed doors with Robert Lighthizer, the trade representative, representatives from Canada and that's -- they're trying to do something by the end of next week. President Trump is threatening to change it or pull out of it on his own, can he do it? There's a lot of pushback in Congress. Again, Europe and Mexico have just inked a trade deal. We're getting left behind and this could roil markets. I think --

BARTIROMO: Anything is going to roil markets if no NAFTA deal and if the U.S. pulls out and then we've got no trade going on with China and Mexico. I totally agree that the markets looking -- go ahead Dennis, jump in.

GARTMAN: Well, yes. We have to pay attention what's going on in the NAFTA talks because what a lot of people are forgetting to understand is that there's a presidential election coming up in Mexico on July 1st and the fellow who's going to win that unless something untoward is to change is an overt Marxist then we have to pay attention to that fact. We need to get this NAFTA agreement passed and passed very quickly, and if it doesn't pass in the next two or three weeks or certainly in the next month then there's trouble ahead.

KELLY: Dennis, you think we've hit peak market right here and I think one of the things to be cognizant of is that because of the multiples? And you don't think that we should be trading at 18 times earnings, maybe we should be trading times 16 times earnings because we're anticipating to make 150 some dollars this year in earnings on the S&P 500, next year 170, so the earning story is going to get better, but are what you're saying -- are you saying that people aren't going to be willing to pay up for that?

GARTMAN: I think 18 times earnings is relatively high. We could get to 20 times earnings. I don't -- I don't doubt that for a moment. But what bothers me and what people are not paying attention to is historically, stock markets do indeed make their highs long before economic activity turns down. What ends up happening at the bottom is the monetary authorities begin to impact expansionary. That money moves into equities before it moves into planned equipment and labor, and at the peak as plant, and equipment, and labor demands capital back, and while the monetary authorities are beginning to tighten, there is less -- there is less liquidity to sponsor plant equipment and labor, and so the money comes out of the stock market. It's very normal.

BARTIROMO: So you want to make the cuts for personal permanent.

CASONE: Multi-billion, Maria. Get this, the Wall Street Journal says the DiDi Chuxing is in talks with bankers about going public; possible valuation up to $80 billion. The offering could happen as soon as this year, and that cash will be used for DiDi to expand internationally. If this company went public, DiDi would beat rival Uber to the public markets.

Privacy concerns hitting Match.com users after a glitch re-activated some old accounts. And while the company maintained, it was a limited number of accounts, their current privacy statements says that the company can retain certain information associated with your account even after you close it, even if you get married, have children, there you go. Old accounts are reactivated if you see a password reset e-mail for Match, you don't have an account any more there were go. Match landed in 1995, they're now available in 25 countries. Shares of match grew; actually, up about 50 percent so far this year.

OK, Maria, you may remember we reported on this, there was a big contest to name the next Krispy Kreme donut flavor. A lot of strong opinion on set that day. Two million votes came in and the winner is lemon glaze. Lemon beat out blueberry, caramel, and maple. I know -- I wanted maple. The new donut goes on sale today; only for a week -- whatever, Krispy Kreme. It's only available through Sunday. I forgot who wanted lemon. I was voting for maple, but there was a lot of back and forth on that one. BARTIROMO: You wanted lemon.

BRENBERG: Lemon is the rightful winner here. There's nothing better on a donut than lemon glaze.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon --

BRENBERG: Way better than maple.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon, talk about Uber, they can't even get their IPO out, their valuations gone to $46 billion. The Chinese company, they had to cede control too in China. Now, valued at 80 billion, can you believe it? That's a lemon.

BARTIROMO: Will Uber ever go public.

KELLY: Yes, yes, yes. Their CEO has re-affirmed that they are going to go public in 2019.

MCDOWELL: I've got my head on my hands because some the mornings, you just want to talk about donuts, Kevin. Some morning --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: All business all the time. That's it.

MCDOWELL: You know what, he's our younger brother. And I just have to bust your job. I can't help it. You're my younger brother too.

BRENBERG: The donut eating and talking younger brother.

MCDOWELL: You understand the importance of talking about it?

BRENBERG: Priorities in life.

KELLY: Yes, but I'm just upset we didn't get maple, that's why, so I had to pivot.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think I'm with you on the maple, by the way. Coming up, Mitt Romney's ribbing -- did you see it? Former presidential candidate getting into playoff fever last night with courtside tots during the Utah Jazz playoff game. And forget sports drinks and shoe endorsements, Steph Curry has just landed a major entertainment deal. Sports is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. In the NBA Playoffs, the Houston Rockets are soaring to new heights. Jared Max with all the details. Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Houston, Minnesota has a problem. James Harden pumped the Rocket fuel in the second quarter like the team have never seen. Game three Rockets-Timberwolves. Houston up two games to one. Harden scores 22 points in the second quarter, 22 of the Rockets, 50. One point off the NBA record set 56 years ago. For the most points in the playoff quarter, Harden finish with 36, Rockets win by 19. They only need one more win to advance Team Wolves free,

Game four in Salt Lake City, between the Jazz and Thunder running for Senate in Utah. Former presidential candidate, Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney taunting, talking trash to OKC star, Russell Westbrook. He keeps holding up his fingers that there's four -- four fouls. Eventually, Russell Westbrook gets his fifth foul and the Jazz win by 17. Donovan Mitchell's scored 33. Utah leads three games to one.

Veteran Bay Area T.V. sport anchor and one-time 49ers Receiver Mike Shumann of KGO T.V. in San Francisco allegedly was caught on video last week in San Antonio appearing to steal a jacket that belonged to the Golden State Warriors Head of Security, Ralph Walker. KGO investigating Shumann, reportedly sent home from NBA Playoff coverage.

Move over Lebron James. You're not the only NBA superstar making waves in the entertainment world. Warriors' great Stephen Curry has chosen Sony Entertainment Pictures after cording with several industry giants to sign what is described as a wide-ranging multi-year deal, unanimous media -- that's the company that Steph created recently. Film, television, electronics gaming, virtual reality, it's all there for Steph whose production lot will be in Culver City at Sony Pictures -- life after basketball.

On one side, we have Rob Gronkowski, the New England Patriots Tight End. And on the other, Rob Gronkowski, just Gronkowski, the 3-year-old cult, named for the Patriots' tight end. Rob Gronkowski, the player, recently bought minority stake in the stakes horse, Gronkowski, who is set to run in next month's Kentucky Derby. But, Gronkowski, the horse, had a spike and fever last weekend, and Gronkowski is not going to be running the Kentucky Derby, and that's going to be May 5th at Churchill Downs. Rob Gronkowski, the person, expressing his lament. Well, I want to know who gets back on the field first: Rob Gronkowski the player or Rob Gronkowski the horse?

KELLY: I think Rob Gronkowski should run the Kentucky Derby, he's the true beast. I bet he could outrun that horse.

MAX: He said he wanted to get on that horse.

KELLY: Oh, he did?

MAX: And that was scary right of at that.

KELLY: Would he do it shirtless?

MAX: I don't know what he'd do, but he's got a four time the body mass of a jockey so.

BARTIROMO: Hey, how about this: racing champ, Matt Kenseth, to make a return to NASCAR, Dagen. Big news for NASCAR.

MCDOWELL: It's kind of an exclamation point on what's been going on in the sport. Matt Kenseth is returning. He's going to part-time drive for Roush Racing this -- the rest of this year. He's spent about a dozen years racing for Roush, that's where he was when he won his only cup championship that was back 2003 before the current playoff series was introduced. Then, he raced for Joe Gibbs racing. Joe Gibbs racing replaced him with the younger cheaper driver, which is a testament to what's happening in the sport, is they want young blood. Again, it's not just the ladies who get cast aside when they get a little bit older, it's the men the too. They want young blood because they think millennials, that will attract to advertising dollars and they're a lot cheaper. So, they're trying to get the salaries down on these drives and attract ads -- attract ad dollars. Matt Kenseth, luckily, is getting back --

KELLY: Is part-time driving, is that a wave of the future? I've never heard really, kind of, part-time.

MCDOWELL: Maybe, I highly doubt it, because it makes it very hard for somebody to race, somebody who's only in the car part of the time. And I think that would impossible for you to -- if you're only racing part-time, impossible to win a championship.

BRENBERG: Kevin, I don't think you can get into it.

KELLY: OK. I've got a day job.

MCDOWELL: Yes, that was it. That was the first sexist comment I've made.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: But I said it, so.

MAX: Hey, how about -- Jenny Cavnar last time, very cool calls of baseball game, play-by-play for the Colorado Rockies' first woman, who 25 years ago.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was cool.

MAX: Cool stuff.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. Catch Jared's sports report Fox News Headlines 24/7 or SiriusXM 115. Still ahead, full steam ahead for phase two of tax reform. Kevin Brady in the studio, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, April 24th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

urn:contentItem:5S64-KB31-JBHT-D1J1-00000-00Mike Pompeo Advances Out Of Committee With Favorable Recommendation, Following Paul Flipping His Vote; Iran To Trump: Stay In Nuclear Deal or 'Face Severe Consequences'; Protests Expected At Wells Fargo Shareholder Meeting Today; Retirement Realities2018-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisMike Pompeo Advances Out Of Committee With Favorable Recommendation, Following Paul Flipping His Vote; Iran To Trump: Stay In Nuclear Deal or 'Face Severe Consequences'; Protests Expected At Wells Fargo Shareholder Meeting Today; Retirement RealitiesLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Tuesday, April 24th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast, a blue chip earnings blitz today. Six Dow components all reporting their first-quarter earnings before the opening bell. Caterpillar leader the way beating expectations on both profit and revenue while also raising full year guidance. The stock is up. The strong results looking to Dow futures indicating a pretty good rally at the start of trading this morning. This is right around the high of the morning up 150 points on the Dow two-thirds of one percent. S&P is also up two-thirds of a percent as does the NASDAQ for the gain of 38 points right now. Alphabet beating expectations on both profit and revenue last night, but the company is raising concerns about expenses as we expected. The stock is down this morning, one half of one percent in the premarket.

Newer markets closed mostly lower yesterday weighed down by yields -- rising bond yields as the 10 year crept closer to three percent. The DowIndustrials were down 14 points, fractional move on a percentage basis. S&P was up a fraction and the NASDAQ was down about a quarter of a percent, 17 points. The Dow was down for a fourth day in a row. That was the longest losing streak since March. In Europe this morning, the indices look like with the FT-100 showing a gain of 25. The CAC Quarante is up fractionally and the DAX Index is up 28 points. That's a quarter of a percent higher. In Asia overnight, stocks closing mostly higher with the exception of Korea. Best performer was Shanghai in China the top performer up at two percent on the session. In open book for the first time, Facebook is revealing its secret rules for user posts where the company says crosses the line. And then a change of heart, Kentucky Senator Rand Paul reversed his stance and cleared the way for President Trump's Secretary of State nominee, Mike Pompeo.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. RAND PAUL (R-KY), SENATE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE: I've been opposed to this nomination for a long time. I hope that they'll let Trump be Trump and that Pompeo will be a constructive influences and not a destructive one. But from what I've been told and listened to with director I think that he is open and understands that his job is -- that the president is his boss.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I'll speak with the Kentucky Senator Rand Paul coming up about his Pompeo decision. Join us at 8:30 this morning in about 30 minutes for that special interview. And then cashing in on the crypto craze, the details as Goldman Sachs makes its first hire for the cryptocurrency market. All those stories coming up Tuesday morning. And joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network Dagen McDowell, The King's College Business Economics Professor Brian Brenberg, and Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly. Great to see everybody.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Yes. It's great to be here especially during earnings week.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: A third of the S&P reporting earnings this week.

BRIAN BRENBERG, BUSINESS ECONOMICS PROFESSOR, THE KING'S COLLEGE: And having a little effect today. The Dow is up. There are some good news coming already this morning. Maybe CAC won't dominate the week. Maybe some of these bread and butter companies in the economy will dominate the - -

BARTIROMO: Oh, you got Amazon coming out on Thursday. You got Qualcomm and Intel coming out tomorrow and Thursday.

KELLY: And Pulte actually reported this morning and the home builders are doing exceptionally well. They've consistently beat. There were worries about, you know, with rising interest rates how that's going to affect. But we have a limited supply of housing in the United States here. It's a big over hang and that's why you're seeing the rental markets still do well in face of that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: With home building and construction they'll watch for rising import costs, watch for rising inflation. There were a bunch of stories being passed around last week about condo developers killing projects and say Toronto because of the rising material costs, and that was one of the things that fueled the move out of treasury bonds here I think. And, again, I think that if you -- if you top 30 percent yield on 10 year could be very, very rough going through the stock market.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, I don't know why though. I mean -- OK. So it's three percent but you're still talking about rock bottom numbers. I mean why would so afraid three percent.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- worrying about the Federal Reserve overreacting to inflation concerns and they start worrying about you hit three, you start worrying about --

(CROSSTALK)

KELLY: It's a bigger percentage move to go from two percent to three percent then three percent to four percent. It's actually -- and in an economy that's going to have over three percent GDP growth this year, you look at the nominal grow -- I mean it's unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Again, it's unprecedented unwinding of unprecedented stimulus from our central bank and I don't think anybody knows how that's going to end.

BARTIROMO: How many people have come on this program and said to us the biggest risk to economic growth right now is the Federal Reserve?

MCDOWELL: Right.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: We talked about it in last year.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Big conversation this morning about all of the above. Joining the conversation Kentucky Senator and Foreign Relations Committee member Rand Paul is with me today. I will get his take on his last minute reversal to vote in favor of Mike Pompeo for Secretary of State, the budget, and a lot more. Don't miss that special interview coming up. But first is our top story is earnings in focus, six Dow companies are reporting earnings this morning including Travelers, 3M, Coca-Cola. They had mixed reports overall. But United Technologies, Caterpillar, and Verizon all beat on earnings and revenue for the first quarter and all of those stocks are trading higher. Caterpillar was one that was really closely watched because that is a big indicator of global economic activity. Futures right now indicating a big gain at the start of trading. Dow Industrials expected to be up 150 points right out of the gate, two- thirds of one percent. The NASDAQ is up half a percent right now, 35 points higher. And joining us right now to talk more about all that is The Gartman Letter Editor and Publisher Dennis Gartman. Dennis, good to see you sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

DENNIS GARTMAN, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER, THE GARTMAN LETTER: Always honored to be on. Thanks for asking me.

BARTIROMO: Before we get to the fundamentals if you will in terms of earnings, let's talk technical because I know you like to look at the charts. What do the charts tell you right now, Dennis, in terms of where we are in the stock market rally?

GARTMAN: I think it's -- it bothers me greatly that we have seen the highs. I'm quite convince in both the market here in the United States and globally, so I'm actually in the long-term quite bearish of equities, I think that we've got the monetary authorities here in the United States already erring upon the side of tighter monetary policy. We've seen the adjusted monetary based on about 10 percent from its highs. That's not going to change anytime soon. We're allowing the monetary base to roll off. We're probably going to see the ECB begin to tighten. The only bank of consequence that won't be tightening the monetary policy anytime soon is the Bank of Japan and as long as the monetary authority is on balance are beginning that process they're taking away the liquidity that has sponsored the Bull market. So technically, I'm actually quite bearish. In the short run, we got so terribly oversold two weeks ago that we're having a good bounce. We shouldn't be surprised by this, but if we took the Dow up another 150 to 200, I guarantee you I shall be selling.

BARTIROMO: Let's not forget though that there's this narrative right now that things aren't going to slow down. Dagen, they've got this massive balance to walk the Federal Reserve does. Even Robert Kaplan from the Dallas Federal Reserve last week said, he wants this two more rate hikes a total of three for this year because while he's expecting 2.6 percent or 2.7 percent growth this year, he thinks growth plummets down to one and three-quarters percent by the end of '19, so there's this narrative that things are going to start slowing down in a big way.

MCDOWELL: And that's something -- that echoes how Stephanie Pomboy has felt about this economy. But to -- what we're talking about the Federal Reserve winding down that balance sheet, that's -- they've laid out a plan to do that. And it would require something really extreme and dramatic in the economy for them to change course at this point on that note. And I don't think people really understand what this economy looks like with the markets look like without all of that buying by Federal Reserve, and one thing I would just point out and it's to kind of pivot a little bit but watch these NAFTA negotiations to sort of going on. They resumed today behind closed doors with Robert Lighthizer, the trade representative, representatives from Canada and that's -- they're trying to do something by the end of next week. President Trump is threatening to change it or pull out of it on his own, can he do it? There's a lot of pushback in Congress. Again, Europe and Mexico have just inked a trade deal. We're getting left behind and this could roil markets. I think --

BARTIROMO: Anything is going to roil markets if no NAFTA deal and if the U.S. pulls out and then we've got no trade going on with China and Mexico. I totally agree that the markets looking -- go ahead Dennis, jump in.

GARTMAN: Well, yes. We have to pay attention what's going on in the NAFTA talks because what a lot of people are forgetting to understand is that there's a presidential election coming up in Mexico on July 1st and the fellow who's going to win that unless something untoward is to change is an overt Marxist then we have to pay attention to that fact. We need to get this NAFTA agreement passed and passed very quickly, and if it doesn't pass in the next two or three weeks or certainly in the next month then there's trouble ahead.

KELLY: Dennis, you think we've hit peak market right here and I think one of the things to be cognizant of is that because of the multiples? What ends up happening at the bottom is the monetary authorities begin to impact expansionary. That money moves into equities before it moves into planned equipment and labor, and at the peak as plant, and equipment, and labor demands capital back, and while the monetary authorities are beginning to tighten, there is less -- there is less liquidity to sponsor plant equipment and labor, and so the money comes out of the stock market. BARTIROMO: So you want to make the cuts for personal permanent.

LOTTER: Thank you.

ELROD: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: for weighing in on all of this. By the way, the President has said (INAUDIBLE) he's not going to fire Robert Mueller. So I don't know why, you know, this question keeps coming up.

MCDOWELL: Because the, media, every time that he is near a microphone, people are shouting the question at him, are you going to fire Bob Mueller? Are you going to fire Bob Mueller? So this is an idea, looking at it from my perspective, they are goading him.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It says if members of the media are goading him to fire Bob Mueller. And it's -- you know what it had? It's a narrative that's basically concocted by people --

BARTIROMO: Muddy the waters. Keep money in the waters. All right, coming up, China's largest ride-hailing company, reportedly revving up its IPO plans, the jaw-dropping valuation for the company, coming up. And then Krispy Kreme celebrates spring with a limited-edition donut, but you have to act fast for this tasty treat. Plus, two big interviews, coming up, Senator Rand Paul and House Ways and Means Committee Chairman, Kevin Brady, join me later on in the program. Back in a moment, right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news overnight, a major Chinese ride hailing company reportedly gears up for a multibillion-dollar IPO. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CASONE: Multi-billion, Maria. Get this, the Wall Street Journal says the DiDi Chuxing is in talks with bankers about going public; possible valuation up to $80 billion. The offering could happen as soon as this year, and that cash will be used for DiDi to expand internationally. If this company went public, DiDi would beat rival Uber to the public markets.

Privacy concerns hitting Match.com users after a glitch re-activated some old accounts. And while the company maintained, it was a limited number of accounts, their current privacy statements says that the company can retain certain information associated with your account even after you close it, even if you get married, have children, there you go. Old accounts are reactivated if you see a password reset e-mail for Match, you don't have an account any more there were go. Match landed in 1995, they're now available in 25 countries. Shares of match grew; actually, up about 50 percent so far this year.

OK, Maria, you may remember we reported on this, there was a big contest to name the next Krispy Kreme donut flavor. A lot of strong opinion on set that day. Two million votes came in and the winner is lemon glaze. Lemon beat out blueberry, caramel, and maple. I know -- I wanted maple. The new donut goes on sale today; only for a week -- whatever, Krispy Kreme. It's only available through Sunday. I forgot who wanted lemon. I was voting for maple, but there was a lot of back and forth on that one. BARTIROMO: You wanted lemon.

BRENBERG: Lemon is the rightful winner here. There's nothing better on a donut than lemon glaze.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon --

BRENBERG: Way better than maple.

KELLY: Speaking of lemon, talk about Uber, they can't even get their IPO out, their valuations gone to $46 billion. The Chinese company, they had to cede control too in China. Now, valued at 80 billion, can you believe it? That's a lemon.

BARTIROMO: Will Uber ever go public.

KELLY: Yes, yes, yes. Their CEO has re-affirmed that they are going to go public in 2019.

MCDOWELL: I've got my head on my hands because some the mornings, you just want to talk about donuts, Kevin. Some morning --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: All business all the time. That's it.

MCDOWELL: You know what, he's our younger brother. And I just have to bust your job. I can't help it. You're my younger brother too.

BRENBERG: The donut eating and talking younger brother.

MCDOWELL: You understand the importance of talking about it?

BRENBERG: Priorities in life.

KELLY: Yes, but I'm just upset we didn't get maple, that's why, so I had to pivot.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I think I'm with you on the maple, by the way. Coming up, Mitt Romney's ribbing -- did you see it? Former presidential candidate getting into playoff fever last night with courtside tots during the Utah Jazz playoff game. And forget sports drinks and shoe endorsements, Steph Curry has just landed a major entertainment deal. Sports is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. In the NBA Playoffs, the Houston Rockets are soaring to new heights. Jared Max with all the details. Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS SPORTSCASTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Houston, Minnesota has a problem. James Harden pumped the Rocket fuel in the second quarter like the team have never seen. Game three Rockets-Timberwolves. Houston up two games to one. Harden scores 22 points in the second quarter, 22 of the Rockets, 50. One point off the NBA record set 56 years ago. For the most points in the playoff quarter, Harden finish with 36, Rockets win by 19. They only need one more win to advance Team Wolves free,

Game four in Salt Lake City, between the Jazz and Thunder running for Senate in Utah. Former presidential candidate, Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney taunting, talking trash to OKC star, Russell Westbrook. He keeps holding up his fingers that there's four -- four fouls. Eventually, Russell Westbrook gets his fifth foul and the Jazz win by 17. Donovan Mitchell's scored 33. Utah leads three games to one.

Veteran Bay Area T.V. sport anchor and one-time 49ers Receiver Mike Shumann of KGO T.V. in San Francisco allegedly was caught on video last week in San Antonio appearing to steal a jacket that belonged to the Golden State Warriors Head of Security, Ralph Walker. KGO investigating Shumann, reportedly sent home from NBA Playoff coverage.

Move over Lebron James. You're not the only NBA superstar making waves in the entertainment world. Warriors' great Stephen Curry has chosen Sony Entertainment Pictures after cording with several industry giants to sign what is described as a wide-ranging multi-year deal, unanimous media -- that's the company that Steph created recently. Film, television, electronics gaming, virtual reality, it's all there for Steph whose production lot will be in Culver City at Sony Pictures -- life after basketball.

On one side, we have Rob Gronkowski, the New England Patriots Tight End. And on the other, Rob Gronkowski, just Gronkowski, the 3-year-old cult, named for the Patriots' tight end. Rob Gronkowski, the player, recently bought minority stake in the stakes horse, Gronkowski, who is set to run in next month's Kentucky Derby. But, Gronkowski, the horse, had a spike and fever last weekend, and Gronkowski is not going to be running the Kentucky Derby, and that's going to be May 5th at Churchill Downs. Rob Gronkowski, the person, expressing his lament. Well, I want to know who gets back on the field first: Rob Gronkowski the player or Rob Gronkowski the horse?

KELLY: I think Rob Gronkowski should run the Kentucky Derby, he's the true beast. I bet he could outrun that horse.

MAX: He said he wanted to get on that horse.

KELLY: Oh, he did?

MAX: And that was scary right of at that.

KELLY: Would he do it shirtless?

MAX: I don't know what he'd do, but he's got a four time the body mass of a jockey so.

BARTIROMO: Hey, how about this: racing champ, Matt Kenseth, to make a return to NASCAR, Dagen. Big news for NASCAR.

MCDOWELL: It's kind of an exclamation point on what's been going on in the sport. Matt Kenseth is returning. He's going to part-time drive for Roush Racing this -- the rest of this year. He's spent about a dozen years racing for Roush, that's where he was when he won his only cup championship that was back 2003 before the current playoff series was introduced. Then, he raced for Joe Gibbs racing. Joe Gibbs racing replaced him with the younger cheaper driver, which is a testament to what's happening in the sport, is they want young blood. Again, it's not just the ladies who get cast aside when they get a little bit older, it's the men the too. They want young blood because they think millennials, that will attract to advertising dollars and they're a lot cheaper. So, they're trying to get the salaries down on these drives and attract ads -- attract ad dollars. Matt Kenseth, luckily, is getting back --

KELLY: Is part-time driving, is that a wave of the future? I've never heard really, kind of, part-time.

MCDOWELL: Maybe, I highly doubt it, because it makes it very hard for somebody to race, somebody who's only in the car part of the time. And I think that would impossible for you to -- if you're only racing part-time, impossible to win a championship.

BRENBERG: Kevin, I don't think you can get into it.

KELLY: OK. I've got a day job.

MCDOWELL: Yes, that was it. That was the first sexist comment I've made.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: But I said it, so.

MAX: Hey, how about -- Jenny Cavnar last time, very cool calls of baseball game, play-by-play for the Colorado Rockies' first woman, who 25 years ago.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that was cool.

MAX: Cool stuff.

BARTIROMO: Jared, thank you. Catch Jared's sports report Fox News Headlines 24/7 or SiriusXM 115. Still ahead, full steam ahead for phase two of tax reform. Kevin Brady in the studio, House Ways and Means Committee Chairman.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, April 24th, your top stories right now, 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

END

urn:contentItem:5H7P-WD31-JCMN-Y22W-00000-00Mild Losses Follow Weak Data; Pfizer, Edwards Rising2015-10-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisMild Losses Follow Weak Data; Pfizer, Edwards Rising

Oct 27, 2015( Stock Market Today: http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> Stocks took moderate losses in early action Tuesday after a wave of mixed earnings reports and weak economic news[1]. The S...00 dropped 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq backed off 0.2% apiece.<nl/> Volume was sharply mixed, rising 19% on the NYSE and falling 71% on the Nasdaq, relative to trade at the same time Monday.<nl/>

The stock market today[2] felt some early drag from the Commerce Department's weaker-than-expected September durable goods report.<nl/> Case-Shiller's 20-City Composite Home Price Index was a bit more positive, rising 0.1% for August. That was up from a 0.2% slip in July and in line with expectations.<nl/> A preliminary reading on October services-sector activity from researcher Markit put its Purchasing Managers' Index at 54.4, down from 55.6 in September and disappointing forecasts for 55.3.<nl/> Consumer sentiment also pulled back in October, with the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index reading 97.6 vs. a revised 102.6 tally for September and far below estimates for 102.5.<nl/> In stocks, Alibaba Group (NYSE:BABA[3]) broad-jumped 7% to join the ranks of big tech names posting solid earnings beats. The China-based diversified Internet play reported a 27% EPS gain and a 32% rise in revenue in its fiscal Q2 — both easily topping consensus forecasts. Mobile revenue rose 183%. Cloud computing and Internet infrastructure revenues rose 128%.<nl/> The company also announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice that it concluded its inquiry and no enforcement action would be recommended. The issue revolved around interactions with a regulator in China.<nl/> Alibaba's heavy-volume gain sent shares back above their 200-day moving average within an 11-month consolidation.<nl/> Yahoo (NASDAQ:YHOO[4]) popped 5%, pulled up by its 15% stake in Alibaba.<nl/> Coach (NYSE:COH[5]) bagged an 8% gain after sneaking past analyst Q3 consensus earnings expectations and meeting revenue forecasts.<nl/> Edwards Lifesciences (NYSE:EW[6]) jumped more than 4% after topping both revenue and earnings expectations for the third quarter. The stock remains just below a 153.45 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.<nl/> Pfizer (NYSE:PFE[7]) grabbed a 3% gain to lead the Dow. The New York-based drugmaker reported a 5% earnings gain vs. expectations for a loss. Revenue fell a less-than-expected 2%. The strong volume gain sent shares past a 34.79 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Pfizer peer Merck (NYSE:MRK[8]) ranked second among the Dow's gains, up nearly 2% after a strong third quarter report.<nl/> Coal miner Consol Energy (NYSE:CNX[9]) tanked 12% after reporting an adjusted loss of 28 cents per share vs. expectations for a 5-cent loss.<nl/> Among leaders, Cadence Design Systems (NASDAQ:CDNS[10]) rose 5% to step out to an early lead among IBD 50 stocks. The developer of automated circuit-design software reported earnings and revenue above forecasts, and gave full-year guidance above consensus views. The gain, in massive trade, triggered a break out past a 21.90 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.<nl/> Cal-Maine Foods (NASDAQ:CALM[11]) took the group's largest loss, down almost 5%. That sent the stock below its 10-week moving average in heavy trade, and 12% below a buy point — triggering two sell signals.<nl/> [ 1]: http://news.investors.com/investing.aspx [ 2]:   http://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/ [ 3]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-alibaba-group-hldg-ads-baba.htm [ 4]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nasdaq-yahoo-inc-yhoo.htm [ 5]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-coach-inc-coh.htm [ 6]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-edwards-lifesciences-cp-ew.htm [ 7]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-pfizer-inc-pfe.htm [ 8]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-merck-and-co-mrk.htm [ 9]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nyse-consol-energy-inc-cnx.htm [ 10]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nasdaq-cadence-design-systems-cdns.htm [ 11]:   http://research.investors.com/quotes/nasdaq-calmaine-foods-inc-calm.htm

– By Ben Egliston, Postdoctoral research fellow, Digital Media Research Centre, Queensland University of Technology There has been a clash of clans in mobile gaming, with angry birds Apple, Google and Epic Games in a saga over in-app payments. Video game d...

– By Ben Egliston, Postdoctoral research fellow, Digital Media Research Centre, Queensland University of Technology There has been a clash of clans in mobile gaming, with angry birds Apple, Google and Epic Games in a saga over in-app payments. Video game developer Epic’s massively popular “” game Fortnite was from Apple’s App Store and the Google Play Store last week. Android players can still download the game directly via the Epic Games mobile app, but for Apple iOS users the decision means no new downloads. Currently installed versions of the game will still work, but iOS players will be unable to update the game and participate in the next season of Fortnite, beginning on August 27. The boot from Apple and Google was in response to Epic’s implementation of a direct in-app payment system, designed to circumvent Apple’s and Google’s own payment systems and their charged on . Epic’s move is a clear violation of Apple’s for app monetisation. The game develoepr also launched the hashtag and aired an in-game parody of Apple’s which, at the time it was released, was Apple’s own response to IBM’s dominance of the computing industry. The parody renders the ad in Fortnite’s graphical style, but retains its original symbolism of oppression and control. Epic, valued at , is attempting to portray itself as Apple did back in 1984: as an underdog facing down a corporate behemoth. The fight escalated this week, with Apple Epic’s enrolment in the Apple Developer Program should it not resolve its breach of Apple’s policy. Membership in the program is required for creating and distributing iOS software. Losing its enrolment wouldn’t just affect Epic, or Fortnite, but potentially anyone using Epic’s widely adopted game development technology. Considering there are more than a billion users of Android and iOS based mobile devices, these punitive responses (particularly from Apple) are being characterised by many as anti-competitive and monopolistic, including by Epic’s chief executive Tim Sweeney. In the past, other companies such as , and have also protested Apple’s 30% fee and strict control over the App Store. But none has so brazenly attacked Apple in the public sphere. Apple’s and Google’s response to this saga has highlighted the power of big tech platforms. As in the case of app stores, these platforms are enclosed and tightly regulated systems. You must play by the owner’s rules, or you’re expelled. Read more: In this case, Apple and Google know their app stores – where millions of users download their apps – are crucial to the financial success of developers on their platform. As such they can exert their power over developers, who don’t really have anywhere else to go. Reminiscent of antitrust charges , critics of Apple and Google have described the tech behemoths as anti-competitive monopolies charging an unreasonable 30% transaction fee. This falls to 15% in the case of subscription-based apps but only after an initial year of Apple charging the 30% fee. For perspective, PayPal only charges of the value of each transaction. Epic argues the mobile games market should be more like the PC market. For instance, Microsoft and Apple don’t get to charge a percentage on every transaction we make through our computers just because they developed the operating system. Given to Apple’s ban, it appears Epic anticipated it and was prepared for this outcome. Is Epic’s lawsuit ultimately aiming to renegotiate the percentage of app store cuts? Maybe Epic believes it’s in a strong enough position to push back against Apple and Google, given Fortnite’s and revenues, as well as the uptake of and value created by software using the Unreal Engine. Or perhaps, given Apple’s previous of Google Stadia and Microsoft xCloud, Epic believes Apple has overplayed its hand. The mobile games industry is a massive source of revenue for app store operators. Perhaps Epic is banking on Apple and Google eventually deciding gaming is too lucrative to cast aside, and hoping they will succumb to renegotiating fees. Epic claims, in the long run, it’s doing this for everyone. If it can force Apple to reduce the 30% fee, or launch an alternative game store on iOS with lower fees, developers will have to sell fewer game copies to make a profit. According to Epic, this means more games for everyone. But it’s also an opportunity for Epic to amplify its platform power by more aggressively expanding its games store into the mobile marketplace. Regardless of what happens now, don’t feel too sorry for Epic. It’s one of the world’s most profitable video game developers and a in its own right (although at 12% it takes a than Apple). While Android players can still access Fortnite, only iOS players who already have the game installed will be able to keep playing. Alternatively, they may have to shell out for a secondhand iPhone with Fortnite installed. And whether or not iOS players will experience much of the upcoming season – that will be determined by Epic’s next move. Read more: – ref. Apple, Google and Fortnite’s stoush is a classic case of how far big tech will go to retain power – – –

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60PD-5RY1-F07F-81HN-00000-00MIL-Evening Report: Facebook and Google used to be the future of news. But now...2020-08-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisNEWSMIL-Evening Report: Facebook and Google used to be the future of news. But now...

– By James Meese, Research fellow, RMIT University Given the about the reforms proposed for the news media sector, you would be forgiven for thinking Google and Facebook are the only game in town. The planned reforms arose from last year’s by the Australia... – By James Meese, Research fellow, RMIT University Given the about the reforms...

– By James Meese, Research fellow, RMIT University Given the about the reforms proposed for the news media sector, you would be forgiven for thinking Google and Facebook are the only game in town. The planned reforms arose from last year’s by the Australia...

– By James Meese, Research fellow, RMIT University Given the about the reforms proposed for the news media sector, you would be forgiven for thinking Google and Facebook are the only game in town. The planned reforms arose from last year’s by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), which focused squarely on the corporate behaviour of these two tech behemoths. It is clear Google and Facebook will be the first platforms regulated under the draft mandatory code that will potentially for content produced by Australian news media companies. The move is a response to what the ACCC as “a significant bargaining power imbalance […] between Australian news media businesses and Google and Facebook”. This idea that news companies are essentially stuck with Google and Facebook, for better or worse, is a common view. Yet while that might have been true a few years ago, media companies are realising there are other ways to cultivate readers, and there’s no need to be beholden to tech platforms that generate clicks but . The completely changed newsroom practices over the past decade, as journalists have weighed editorial considerations against audience metrics. This dependency developed at a time when major platforms, particularly Facebook, were engaging substantially with the distribution of news. But in recent years this trend has declined, as governments have begun to regulate platforms in response to concerns over “”. Facebook performed perhaps the most public pivot, in January 2018 to promote content from users’ friends and family. As a result, traffic to news sites fell, leaving profit-starved media companies to pursue alternative strategies or simply . Read more: In our research, , we spoke to 15 Australian journalists and editors who had collectively worked across 11 media companies after the dust had settled from the 2019 crisis. We asked them whether their companies still depend on Facebook for traffic, or whether they have moved to other platforms, or are now doing something else entirely to cultivate their readership. Many respondents, particularly those who had worked at newer companies focused on , revealed they had followed the demands of the Facebook algorithm at times. They had pivoted to video and had focused on share counts. However, respondents working at older media companies also noted that lots of readers still visited their publication’s home page, which challenges the idea that companies depend totally on Facebook. Companies were also exploring different ways of generating revenue. These included placing ads inside content (known as ) and holding events. The standout trend, however, was a renewed focus on , ensuring that a certain percentage of readers actually paid money for the news product at some point. The Conversation (which does not charge for access to its content) was one of the newsrooms that saw a steep drop in traffic as a result of the January 2018 algorithm change. As such, it has pivoted its digital strategy to prioritise the channels over which it has the most control, particularly its . That’s not to say companies have stopped trying to engage with big platforms. Many are consciously trying to make their news easy to find via Google search (a process called . Some companies (including The Conversation) have also begun distributing news through Instagram (which is owned by Facebook). Yet although the big platforms are doubtless here to stay, our research reveals a distinctly changed relationship between news and social media, compared with the past decade. Many companies, particularly newer ones like Buzzfeed and Vice, previously built huge audiences off the back of social media, and grew at a dizzying rate as a result. Now, companies are more interested in securing a stable revenue stream than in harvesting clicks. This has become even more important amid the economic chaos caused by COVID-19. Advertising spending has dried up, leading to . This suggests news media are still struggling to secure an alternative income stream to plug the hole in advertising revenue. The big question is whether big tech platforms will step in and help fill the gap by making financial contributions to news providers. Google’s against the draft mandatory code suggests they are deeply unwilling to do this. Read more: Our research shows the relationship between news media and big tech platforms is far from straightforward. This is supported by a , which found that while many young people access news through social media, older people still prefer television or news websites. Not every Australian gets their news via social media. There may come a time when platforms become the central access point for news, but it hasn’t happened yet. This doesn’t mean the ACCC should abandon platform regulation, but it does mean news companies are probably wise to find other ways of reaching their readers while they still can. – ref. Facebook and Google used to be the future of news. But now media companies need more strings to their bow – – –

The new device packs more computing power and a sharper screen than... – By Marcus Carter, Senior Lecturer in Digital Cultures, SOAR Fellow., University of Sydney Facebook has...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60VX-N5H1-F07F-80MM-00000-00MIL-Evening Report: Facebook’s virtual reality push is about data, not gaming2020-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisNEWSMIL-Evening Report: Facebook’s virtual reality push is about data, not gaming

– By Marcus Carter, Senior Lecturer in Digital Cultures, SOAR Fellow., University of Sydney Facebook has the latest version of its successful standalone virtual reality (VR) headset, the . The new device packs more computing power and a sharper screen than... – By Marcus Carter, Senior Lecturer in Digital Cultures, SOAR Fellow., University of Sydney Facebook has...

– By Marcus Carter, Senior Lecturer in Digital Cultures, SOAR Fellow., University of Sydney Facebook has the latest version of its successful standalone virtual reality (VR) headset, the . The new device packs more computing power and a sharper screen than...

– By Marcus Carter, Senior Lecturer in Digital Cultures, SOAR Fellow., University of Sydney Facebook has the latest version of its successful standalone virtual reality (VR) headset, the . The new device packs more computing power and a sharper screen than its predecessor, and is also US$100 cheaper. The Oculus Quest 2 is the latest step in Facebook’s long-term strategy of making VR more accessible and popular. Facebook recently brought all its VR work under the umbrella of , it has announced new applications like the , and will also for future Oculus devices. The compulsory link to Facebook has many consumers concerned, considering the social media giant’s . VR and its cousin, augmented reality (AR), are perhaps the most data-extractive digital sensors we’re likely to invite into our homes in the next decade. Facebook acquired VR company Oculus in 2014 for . But where Oculus originally aimed at gamers, Facebook boss Mark Zuckerberg wants VR for social media. This may well be right. VR affords a strong feeling of embodied presence that offers new possibilities for entertainment, training, learning and connecting with others at a distance. But if the VR future is the one Facebook is “” on, it will function via the company’s existing social computing platform and business model of extracting data to deliver targeted advertisements. A VR headset collects data about the user, but also about the outside world. This is one of the key of emerging “mixed reality” technologies. As AmericanVR researcher : …commercial VR systems typically track body movements 90 times per second to display the scene appropriately, and high-end systems record 18 types of movements across the head and hands. Consequently, spending 20 minutes in a VR simulation leaves just under 2 million unique recordings of body language. The way you move your body can be , like a fingerprint, so everything you do in VR could be traced back to your individual identity. Facebook’s Oculus Quest headsets also use outward-facing cameras to track and map their surroundings. In late 2019 they “don’t collect and store images or 3D maps of your environment on our servers today”. Note the word today , which tech journalist makes clear the company is not ruling out anything in the future. Facebook wants to collect this data to facilitate its plans for augmented reality (AR). Where VR takes a user to a fully virtual environment, AR combines virtual elements with our real surroundings. Last year Facebook unveiled the Live Maps application, a vision of an expansive surveillance apparatus presumably powered by AR glasses and data collected from Oculus Insight. Live Maps will provide many minor conveniences for Facebook users, like letting you know you’ve left your keys on the coffee table. Now Facebook have announced their first steps towards making this a reality: . This will involve people wearing glasses-like sensors around Seattle and the San Francisco Bay area, to collect the data to build what Wired co-founder Kevin Kelly calls ”, the next big tech platform. Read more: People are rightly concerned about the ethical implications of this kind of data extraction. Alongside Project Aria, Facebook launched its page, and they’re already quick to emphasise that faces and license plates will be blurred in this data collection. As we have , framing questions about VR and AR surveillance in terms of individual privacy suits companies like Facebook very well. That’s because their previous failings are actually in the (un)ethical use of data (as in the case of ) and their . Read more: Groups like the recognise these emerging issues, and are beginning work on to shape VR and AR development. Many emerging technologies encounter what is known as : it is hard to predict the various impacts of a technology until it is extensively developed and widely used, but by then it is almost impossible to control or change. We see this playing out right now, in efforts to . As David Watts argues, big tech designs its own rules of ethics to : Feelgood, high-level data ethics principles are not fit for the purpose of regulating big tech … The harms linked to big tech can only be addressed by proper regulation. What might regulation of Facebook’s VR look like? Germany offers one such response – their antitrust regulations have resulted in Facebook . We can only hope the technology doesn’t become too entrenched to be changed, or challenged. But regulation has not always stopped Facebook in the past, who paid out to settle a lawsuit for breaching biometric privacy laws. In the multi-billion dollar world of big-tech, it’s all a cost of doing business. Another question we might ask ourselves is whether Facebook’s virtual-reality future and others like it really need to exist. Maybe there are other ways to avoid forgetting your keys. – ref. Facebook’s virtual reality push is about data, not gaming – – –

value.Title: MIL-Evening Report: Google and Facebook shouldn’t subsidise journalism, but the government could
value.Overview: – By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian ... – By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60XC-9YF1-JCSC-J380-00000-00MIL-Evening Report: Google and Facebook shouldn’t subsidise journalism, but the government could2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:10:11ZLexisNexisNEWSMIL-Evening Report: Google and Facebook shouldn’t subsidise journalism, but the government could

– By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian ... – By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You...

– By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian ...

– By Richard Holden, Professor of Economics, UNSW You might have missed it – what with the biggest recession since the 1930s and a pandemic going on – but there may be big, and bad, changes happening to a media landscape near you. Right now the Australian government is considering amending the Competition and Consumer Act 2010 to force Google and Facebook to pay local commercial media organisations for the sharing of their content on the digital platforms. The proposed by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will require the tech and media companies to make terms through “mandatory binding arbitration”. It will also oblige them to divulge parts of their core intellectual property (such Google’s search algorithm). It has been lauded as a world-first in addressing the power imbalance between the platforms and traditional news organisations. What this was all about was the imbalance in bargaining power, the market failure that comes from that, and underpayment for news having a detrimental effect on Australian society. Who could argue with that? Even federal treasurer Josh Frydenberg has described it as “a question of fairness”. But from an economic standpoint the whole bargaining code is hopelessly confused. It fails to properly understand the source of competitive pressure for media companies, and why they have lost revenues over the last 15 years. Mandatory binding arbitration between tech and media companies is also a completely inappropriate policy tool to achieve the public policy goal of fostering high-quality journalism. As I have for the Stigler Center at the University of Chicago Booth School of Business, making the code law risks doing serious harm to Australian consumers while shovelling money to large media companies like Nine Entertainment and News Corp Australia. Faced with the prospect of having to divulge key intellectual property, it would not be surprising if Google and Facebook simply prefer not to be in the Australian market. Millions of Australians using Google, YouTube and Facebook will lose out. Between 2002 and 2018, consulting firm total annual revenue for Australian newspapers fell from A$4.4 billion to A$3.0 billion. Almost all of this was due to lost classified advertising revenue, worth A$1.5 billion in 2002 but just A$200 million in 2018. “That’s Google’s fault,” you might cry. Actually no. The vast bulk of lost classified advertising revenue was due to online “pure-plays” such as Seek, Domain and Carsales. Google and Facebook took basically none of this revenue. Read more: The media companies were sitting on a gold mine of classified advertising. Then there was massive technological disruption due to the internet and smart phones. That, as they say in the classics, is show business. It doesn’t justify making companies who happened to succeed in an adjacent space at the same time fork over a chunk of their revenues. If big tech companies were somehow allowing you and me free access to content we would otherwise have to pay for, there might be a case to answer. That would be like Google Maps not only giving you directions to a restaurant but the means to also avoid paying for your meal. But using a search engine does not allow you to get free meals, nor to get around a news organisation’s pay wall. Read more: In fact, having their content pop up in search results, or shared on social media, helps Australian media companies to attract readers and sell subscriptions – something that now accounts for roughly half the revenues of some leading players such as The Australian. All you get for “free” is a snippet of a line or two from the search. For instance, when I searched for news about recently deceased US Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, I got this: If you can figure out the full content of the article from that snippet, you should be using your superpowers for other, more lucrative purposes. There is a very real risk this misguided code will end up becoming law. An overzealous regulator has proposed something that stands to benefit the big media companies, who are – not surprisingly – strongly for it. Those same media companies have huge influence over public perceptions and the fate of politicians. It will be a brave elected representative who pushes back on the proposed code and draft legislation. But if politicians were serious about resolving the real issue at stake in all of this, they would act more directly. Like newspapers all around the world, Australian media and journalists are under pressure – and one thing most people agree on is that high-quality news and journalism is critical to a well-functioning democracy. Read more: Whatever the market forces that have slashed the funding of such journalism, there is a strong case for government intervention. But if the Australian government wants to subsidise high-quality journalism, it should do it itself. With the 10-year bond rate less than 1%, it would cost the government just A$18 million a year to fund the interest bill on A$2 billion of media subsidies a year. That’s 72 cents per Australian a year. And all without driving away the hugely valuable services of companies like Google and Facebook that Australian consumers love. – ref. Google and Facebook shouldn’t subsidise journalism, but the government could – – –
